SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: IN THE STATES -- GOVERNORS; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 1118 words

HEADLINE: Ex-Budget Chief Unseats Democrat in Indiana; Democrats Retain North Carolina

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

 BODY:
Mitch Daniels, the White House budget director under President Bush, won the Indiana governor's race last night, defeating the Democratic incumbent, Joseph E. Kernan.
 Mr. Daniels, who also served in the Reagan White House and as a top executive at Eli Lilly & Company, deposed Mr. Kernan, who became governor in September 2003 after Gov. Frank O'Bannon died of a stroke. Mr. Kernan, a prisoner of war in Vietnam and the former mayor of South Bend, had made Mr. Daniels's service in the Bush White House a campaign issue, criticizing his opponent in speeches and advertisements. But he could not overcome Mr. Daniels's money or name recognition in a state won by Mr. Bush in 2000 and again this year. 
 The national Republican party poured $2.6 million into the Indiana race on Mr. Daniels's behalf.
 Incumbent governors in Delaware, North Dakota, Vermont and North Carolina won re-election last night. The Democratic candidate in West Virginia kept the governor's office in the party's hands.
 Gov. Ruth Ann Minner of Delaware, a Democrat and the state's first female governor, held onto her office in an unexpectedly close race, while Gov. John Hoeven of North Dakota, a Republican, easily won a second term.
 Jim Douglas, the moderate Republican governor of Vermont who first won the office in 2002 after Gov. Howard Dean left the job to run for president, won another two-year term. He has held elective office in Vermont for most of the last 30 years.
 Michael Easley, the Democratic governor of North Carolina, also won re-election, keeping the seat in his party's hands, even as President Bush carried his state. He succeeded Jim Hunt, the popular Democrat who served two terms as governor in the 1990's.
 In West Virginia, Joseph Manchin, the secretary of state and long a familiar figure in state politics, will become the next governor. The office opened unexpectedly this year after the incumbent, Bob Wise, also a Democrat, admitted an extramarital affair and bowed out of the race.
 Eleven states were picking governors yesterday, five of them with no incumbent on the ballot. Before the elections, Republicans held 28 governors' offices and Democrats 22. Despite a number of competitive races this year and some probable party shifts, voting results and projections indicated that that overall balance of statehouse power would change by no more than one or two seats.
 The issues on which these races were decided were intensely local. Several states that went decisively for President Bush or Senator John Kerry appeared poised to elect a governor of the other party. Tight budgets and their effects on public services across the board were the main motivating factors for voters, although several states also presented candidates with sharply different styles and personal stories.
 There was no single marquee race for governor this year, but Indiana, Missouri, Montana, New Hampshire, Utah and Washington had closely fought contests. Races in Delaware, North Carolina, North Dakota, Vermont and West Virginia were less competitive by Election Day.
 Among the most closely-watched governors' elections was the race in Missouri, where the state auditor, Claire McCaskill, a Democrat, faced Matt Blunt, the Republican secretary of state and son of Representative Roy Blunt, the third-ranking Republican in the House. The race was close all fall. Ms. McCaskill defeated the incumbent, Bob Holden, in the Democratic primary. 
 Ms. McCaskill and Mr. Blunt attacked each other's records and accused each other of changing positions. Ms. McCaskill would be the state's first female governor. Mr. Blunt generally hewed to Republican party positions, including opposition to some forms of stem cell research and support for a state constitutional amendment banning gay marriage.
 New Hampshire's incumbent governor, Craig Benson, was being challenged by John Lynch, a businessman who specializes in turning around troubled companies and who is a former chairman of the University of New Hampshire Board of Trustees. Mr. Benson, a wealthy technology entrepreneur, campaigned as a fiscal conservative, supporter of the death penalty and opponent of gay marriage.
 New Hampshire elects a governor every two years.
 The governor's race in Utah pitted two respected political families against each other in a race for an open seat, but the Republican prevailed in this reliably Republican state. John Huntsman Jr., the Republican scion of a wealthy chemical manufacturing family, a former ambassador to Singapore and a former deputy trade representative, defeated Scott Matheson, a Democrat from a prominent political family. Mr. Matheson is the son of a former governor and brother of a member of Congress from Utah, Jim. Like most other governor's races around the nation, the debate focused on jobs and the economy.
 Governor Minner, 69, who rose to the state's top office from an impoverished background, is a fiscal conservative but a moderate on social issues. Among her first acts on taking office in 2001 was to order broad cuts in state spending. She has tried to improve the state's health programs and helped push through a tough ban on indoor smoking. She has also tried to limit the expansion of gambling in Delaware.
 She defeated Bill Lee, 68, a Republican who is former Superior Court judge.
 In North Dakota, Governor Hoeven, a former banker and a onetime Democrat, won the office as a Republican in 2000 in his first political campaign. This year he pointed to improvements in the state economy, including a modest increase in employment and incomes in the state.
 Mr. Douglas, the Republican who was re-elected governor of Vermont, has engaged in virtually nonstop campaigning for the past 25 years. He served 12 years as secretary of state and 8 years as treasurer before winning the governor's office in 2002. His Democratic opponent, Peter Clavelle, first won office as a Progressive, becoming the mayor of left-leaning Burlington in 1989. He was defeated four year later by a Republican, then won back the office in 1995Mr. Manchin, West Virginia's new governor, defeated Monty Warner, a Republican who is a former Army officer and is now a real estate developer. Mr. Manchin served in both houses of the state legislature and as secretary of state. He managed to unite business and labor interests and has talked about making the state more attractive to businesses and tourists.
 Two other incumbents, Judy Martz of Montana, Republican, and Gary Locke of Washington, a Democrat, also choose not to seek re-election.The Democratic candidate in Montana, Brian Schweitzer, and the Republican, Secretary of State Bob Brown, traded accusations of unethical conduct throughout the fall.

GEOGRAPHIC: INDIANAPOLIS, IN, USA (79%); SOUTH BEND, IN, USA (58%) INDIANA, USA (97%); NORTH CAROLINA, USA (94%); VERMONT, USA (94%); NORTH DAKOTA, USA (93%); WEST VIRGINIA, USA (92%); MONTANA, USA (92%); NEW HAMPSHIRE, USA (92%); DELAWARE, USA (91%); UTAH, USA (79%); MISSOURI, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (97%); VIET NAM (72%) United States; Indiana; Delaware; North Dakota; Vermont; North Carolina; New Hampshire; United States; Utah; Montana; Washington (State)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 3, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Editorial Desk; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 704 words

HEADLINE: Living Poor, Voting Rich

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF. 
E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
In the aftermath of this civil war that our nation has just fought, one result is clear: the Democratic Party's first priority should be to reconnect with the American heartland.
 I'm writing this on tenterhooks on Tuesday, without knowing the election results. But whether John Kerry's supporters are now celebrating or seeking asylum abroad, they should be feeling wretched about the millions of farmers, factory workers and waitresses who ended up voting -- utterly against their own interests -- for Republican candidates.
 One of the Republican Party's major successes over the last few decades has been to persuade many of the working poor to vote for tax breaks for billionaires. Democrats are still effective on bread-and-butter issues like health care, but they come across in much of America as arrogant and out of touch the moment the discussion shifts to values. 
 ''On values, they are really noncompetitive in the heartland,'' noted Mike Johanns, a Republican who is governor of Nebraska. ''This kind of elitist, Eastern approach to the party is just devastating in the Midwest and Western states. It's very difficult for senatorial, Congressional and even local candidates to survive.''
 In the summer, I was home -- too briefly -- in Yamhill, Ore., a rural, working-class area where most people would benefit from Democratic policies on taxes and health care. But many of those people disdain Democrats as elitists who empathize with spotted owls rather than loggers.
 One problem is the yuppification of the Democratic Party. Thomas Frank, author of the best political book of the year, ''What's the Matter With Kansas: How Conservatives Won the Heart of America,'' says that Democratic leaders have been so eager to win over suburban professionals that they have lost touch with blue-collar America.
 ''There is a very upper-middle-class flavor to liberalism, and that's just bound to rub average people the wrong way,'' Mr. Frank said. He notes that Republicans have used ''culturally powerful but content-free issues'' to connect to ordinary voters.
 To put it another way, Democrats peddle issues, and Republicans sell values. Consider the four G's: God, guns, gays and grizzlies.
 One-third of Americans are evangelical Christians, and many of them perceive Democrats as often contemptuous of their faith. And, frankly, they're often right. Some evangelicals take revenge by smiting Democratic candidates.
 Then we have guns, which are such an emotive issue that Idaho's Democratic candidate for the Senate two years ago, Alan Blinken, felt obliged to declare that he owned 24 guns ''and I use them all.'' He still lost.
 As for gays, that's a rare wedge issue that Democrats have managed to neutralize in part, along with abortion. Most Americans disapprove of gay marriage but do support some kind of civil unions (just as they oppose ''partial birth'' abortions but don't want teenage girls to die from coat-hanger abortions). 
 Finally, grizzlies -- a metaphor for the way environmentalism is often perceived in the West as high-handed. When I visited Idaho, people were still enraged over a Clinton proposal to introduce 25 grizzly bears into the wild. It wasn't worth antagonizing most of Idaho over 25 bears.
 ''The Republicans are smarter,'' mused Oregon's governor, Ted Kulongoski, a Democrat. ''They've created ... these social issues to get the public to stop looking at what's happening to them economically.''
 ''What we once thought -- that people would vote in their economic self-interest -- is not true, and we Democrats haven't figured out how to deal with that.''
 Bill Clinton intuitively understood the challenge, and John Edwards seems to as well, perhaps because of their own working-class origins. But the party as a whole is mostly in denial.
 To appeal to middle America, Democratic leaders don't need to carry guns to church services and shoot grizzlies on the way. But a starting point would be to shed their inhibitions about talking about faith, and to work more with religious groups.
 Otherwise, the Democratic Party's efforts to improve the lives of working-class Americans in the long run will be blocked by the very people the Democrats aim to help.

William Safire appears on Thursday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- OHIO; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1039 words

HEADLINE: Ohio Remains A Battleground As Late Voting Delays Count

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN and JAMES DAO; James Dao reported from Columbus for this article, and Ford Fessenden from Cleveland. Albert Salvato contributed reporting from Cincinnati.

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Wednesday, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
For the second straight time, the state of the presidential election rested in the hands of a single state as election officials in Ohio worked well into Wednesday morning counting ballots after a frenzy of late voting kept the polls open late.
 President Bush seemed to hold a strong lead with 51 percent of the vote at 2 a.m., but Senator John Kerry's campaign refused to concede the state. 
 ''It's been a long night, but we've waited four years for this victory,'' Senator John Edwards, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, said. ''We can wait one more night.'' 
 Portending a Florida-like battle over each vote, Mr. Edwards said, ''John Kerry and I made a promise to the American people that in this election, every vote would count, every vote would be counted.''
 Mr. Kerry's campaign manager, Mary Beth Cahill, sent an e-mail message to reporters about 1:30 a.m. saying that 250,000 votes had yet to be counted in Ohio.
 ''We believe when they are, John Kerry will win Ohio,'' she said.
 The uncertainty came at the end of a long day in which hundreds of thousands of voters waited in long lines, and polls were kept open well beyond closing times. The prospect of a drawn-out battle over provisional votes, absentee ballots and even a return to a recount of chads on punch-card voting machines loomed. 
 As other states fell into familiar places, Ohio became the battleground of battlegrounds that it was billed to be throughout the election season. At the end of a long night of uncertainty, George Bush's issues and his ground game gave him a solid, if not quite decisive, lead.
 The candidates spent more time in the state than any other. Mr. Bush talked security, and Mr. Kerry hammered the economy. Mr. Bush sent an army of volunteers into suburban areas to turn out believers, and Mr. Kerry and his allies sent paid workers into the inner city to find new voters.
 In the end, both parties improved on their 2000 performance. Mr. Bush ran better in suburban areas in the southwest part of the state, and he picked up more votes in the rural areas that he had won decisively in 2000. Mr. Kerry reaped more votes than his strategists had hoped for in Cleveland, but did not get enough new voters in the big cities to overcome Mr. Bush's margins elsewhere.
 Democrats still hoped to overcome the lead and had begun to talk about provisional ballots, votes that are cast in the event of a dispute over registration. It was unclear how many provisional ballots were cast, but estimates ranged high enough to make a difference in the margin between the candidates.
 Turnout was strong everywhere. In spite of widespread rain and long lines, the secretary of state said turnout would be 5.8 million, or 73 percent, the highest since 1992. It was so heavy in parts of Columbus, Akron, Cleveland and even rural Knox County -- where hundreds of Kenyon College students waited six hours to vote -- that Democrats ordered volunteers to abandon phone banks and rush food, hot chocolate, chairs, umbrellas and radios to voters who had been waiting in the drenching rain. 
 Republicans, who had proclaimed the superiority of their 72-hour strategy of intensive face-to-face contact in the last three days of the election, were deeply pleased with the results in their most important counties in the southwest part of the state and in the suburbs of Columbus.
 ''We've seen cases across the state where turnout may approach or even surpass records,'' said Jason Mauk, a spokesman for Ohio Republican Party.
 Even in the suburban areas of Cleveland, Republican turnout was high, party officials said. ''We had many precincts where we got every single one of our voters to vote,'' said Jeff Flint, a spokesman for the Cuyahoga County Republican Party.
 Democrats said their turnout strategy worked as well.
 ''In the major counties, we're hitting all our numbers,'' said Dan Trevas, a party spokesman. ''I can't figure out where the uncounted numbers are coming from.''
 Mr. Kerry did extremely well in his political base in the Cleveland area, holding a lead of about 200,000 votes there, significantly better than Vice President Al Gore did in 2000. Mr. Kerry also performed well in Franklin County, which includes the state capital, Columbus.
 But the Democrats' improved performance in those two counties was not enough to close the gap with Mr. Bush, in large part because the Republicans squeezed additional votes out of their traditional political base in the northwest part of the state, the rural western border with Indiana and the conservative suburbs around Cincinnati, Republican strategists said.
 Many tiny rural counties, where Mr. Bush had won 65 percent or more of the vote in 2000, gave him even larger margins this year. Analysts attributed that improved turnout among conservatives in part to a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage that was on the ballot.
 ''The Republicans really galvanized their base with their get-out-the-vote operation, and they did so in large part by taking advantage of cultural issues that were important to Republicans voters,'' said Eric Rademacher, the director of the Ohio Poll at the University of Cincinnati. ''Clearly one of those issues was the constitutional amendment.''
 Mr. Rademacher and other analysts said Mr. Bush's strong showing showed the Republicans had succeeded in moving the debate away from Mr. Kerry's strong suit: the weak economy and the high cost of health care.
 Early on Wednesday morning, Democrats declined to concede the race, arguing that there might be enough provisional ballots outstanding to tip the election to Mr. Kerry. Democrats contend, and many analysts agree, that the majority of those ballots were probably cast by Democrats, who tend to move more often than Republicans, and provisional ballots are more likely to be used by people whose addresses have changed.
 The question was: How many provisional ballots were cast? Secretary of State J. Kenneth Blackwell estimated that the number might be between 130,000 and 150,000. But Democrats asserted it could be as high as 250,000. 
 Provisional ballots are held for 10 days after the election while election workers determine whether the person who cast them is eligible to vote.


GRAPHIC: Photo: In Cleveland at 6 a.m., workers gathered in the rain before going door to door to help people get to the polls. (Photo by Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. P2)

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 633 words

HEADLINE: Election Dominates Markets; Shares Dip Late in Session

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks retreated in late trading amid speculation that surveys of voters leaving the polls were showing Senator John Kerry ahead in the presidential election. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index erased most of its advance and the Dow Jones industrial average snapped a five-day rally. 
 ''There's the old saying that the market favors Republicans and incumbents,'' said Brian Pears, head of equity trading at Victory Capital Management in Cleveland. ''It looks like Kerry is doing better than expected and that caused a sell-off.'' 
 The Dow average fell 18.66 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,035.73, and the S.&P. 500 was little changed, up 0.05 point at 1,130.56. The Nasdaq composite index added 4.92 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,984.79.
 Ten stocks fell for every nine that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, and 1.67 billion shares changed hands, 25 percent above the three-month daily average.
 The Dow average had risen as much as 0.8 percent, while the S.&P. 500 climbed 0.9 percent on declining oil prices and the prospect that the election results would produce a market rally. Speculation that Senator Kerry was leading President Bush in some swing states prompted the sell-off.
 Mr. Kerry led Mr. Bush by 18.1 percentage points in trading on the Iowa Electronic Markets, a nonprofit political betting system run by the University of Iowa, as of 4 p.m. New York time. Two hours earlier, Mr. Bush had a 3.8 percentage point advantage over Mr. Kerry.
 ''There is some concern about change,'' said Wayne Reisner, who helps manage $1.8 billion at Carret Asset Management in New York. ''It's fear of the unknown.''
 Some investors said stocks might decline if the challenger won. ''With Kerry there's the possibility of higher taxes next year,'' said Jon Goebel, chief investment officer at SouthTrust Bank of Alabama. ''You'd like to think this is already reflected in the market, but I think it isn't.''
 Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, fell 10 cents, to $28.70, while Merck lost $1.48, to $26.80. A Standard & Poor's index of drug makers dropped 1.1 percent on concern that Senator Kerry would allow health plans to negotiate lower prices with drug companies.
 An index of utility companies fell 1.7 percent, the biggest decline among the S.&P. 500's 24 industry groups. Investors fear that a Kerry administration may seek to roll back President Bush's tax reduction on dividends. Duke Energy, the No. 1 utility owner in the United States, slid 56 cents, to $24.32. TXU, owner of Texas's largest power company, shed $1.43, to $59.60. 
 Energy companies, which would stand to gain from Mr. Bush's efforts to increase oil production and exploration, also fell. Nabors Industries, the world's largest onshore oil and natural gas driller, dropped 96 cents, to $47.55. A drop in oil prices also sent the group lower. Crude oil for December delivery fell 1 percent, to $49.62 a barrel in New York. 
 Shares of gold miners retreated as gold prices in New York showed the biggest drop in more than two months. Gold for December delivery fell 1.7 percent, to $420.80 an ounce, the steepest decline since Aug. 24. Gold futures last week closed at a 15-year high as some investors bought gold on concern about the election's outcome. Newmont Mining, the world's biggest gold producer, lost $1.01, to $45.81. 
 In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note gained 5/32, to a price of 101 19/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dipped to 4.05 percent from 4.07 percent on Monday.

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: THE PRESIDENCY -- SECURITY; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: On Alert for Terror Activity Timed to Disrupt Election, Agencies Find Little Reason to Worry

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Terrorism command centers were activated in dozens of states and cities throughout the country on Tuesday because of fears of an election-year attack. Security authorities said emergency personnel were on standby alert, but there were no reports of any incidents.
 In the capital, officials at the Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency were stationed at their emergency command posts, but even there officials reported little activity beyond routine reports from their field units, which indicated no sign of terror activity.
 The relative tranquillity of Election Day contrasted with the high anxiety of the preceding months when counterterrorism officials had repeatedly warned of a potentially catastrophic attack by Al Qaeda inside the United States timed to disrupt the electoral process. In recent days, these officials said they had uncovered no evidence of such an operation, after thousands of interviews in the United States and a global effort to track down anti-American extremists. 
 In May, July and August, senior law enforcement and intelligence authorities made urgent public announcements about the terror threat warning that Al Qaeda was almost ready to strike. At the same time, they issued dozens of bulletins to state and local officials advising them to be increasingly vigilant.
 Some officials said they suspected that an attack of some kind might still be coming. They said the period of concern should be extended from the election through the presidential inauguration in January. 
 But over all, it seemed apparent from interviews among counterterrorism officials on Tuesday that the mood of feverish concern had ebbed as the election appeared to have taken place without incident.
 Some hinted that the government might soon downshift its terror warnings. ''Following the election, we will assess the threat environment and the alert status to determine what security posture we will need to have in place based on intelligence assessments,'' said Brian Roehrkasse, the spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security.
 At the Justice Department, Mark Corallo, the spokesman, said: ''We're still working overtime. The F.B.I. and all of our partners at the state and local level are pounding the pavement, pressing sources for information, staying on top of it. We're doing everything we can to detect and disrupt the terrorist threat. And if nothing happens, we're going to be out there tomorrow doing the same thing.''
 Officials said that absence of any tangible sign of an attack had led them to a fresh assessment of the possible significance of a recent videotape by Osama bin Laden, which was first broadcast Friday by the Arab-language satellite network Al Jazeera and transmitted by television outlets around the world.
 On the videotape, Mr. bin Laden directly addressed Americans in an unusually formal statement in which he said: ''Your security is not the hands of Kerry or Bush or Al Qaeda. Your security is in your own hands.''
 It was possible, the officials theorized, that Mr. bin Laden, while he remained a worrisome threat, lacked the resources and personnel to direct an attack in the United States. Instead, they said, he may have decided to resort to a statement in an effort to disrupt the election. 
 Within counterterrorism circles in the government, officials are still debating why they have found so little evidence of an election-year attack, a concern that seemed credible enough to impose extraordinary security measures at the two national political conventions in Boston and New York and other government events, like the Group of 8 economic summit in Georgia this past summer.
 Some counterterrorism officials said they doubted that there was ever a solid basis for believing that Al Qaeda would strike in the United States this year, although others disputed that assessment and said the intelligence about an attack was specific and persuasive.
 Some officials suggested that intensive disruption and detection efforts might have caused Al Qaeda to postpone or cancel its plans, which could still be activated any time the terror network gauged that it had a good chance of successfully carrying them out.
 The most significant threat discovered by the authorities this year, a Qaeda surveillance operation directed at five American financial institutions, has led the authorities to what they now say is a dead end. The detailed reconnaissance plans alarmed the authorities and caused them to elevate the alert level in New York, Newark and Washington.
 The investigation led to a group of eight Qaeda suspects in Britain, including a man who officials said actually carried out the surveillance operation. But the investigation yielded no evidence that the group had been planning to attack the financial institutions or any other targets in the United States, as was initially suspected.

LENGTH: 321 words

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Dropped Again In September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Orders at factories in the United States dropped in September for a second month, evidence that companies may be growing wary about the strength of demand amid high energy prices. Orders for military equipment surged.
 Reduced orders for automobiles, civilian aircraft and nondurable goods like chemicals, food and textiles led to a 0.4 percent decline for September, the Commerce Department said yesterday. Orders fell 0.3 percent in August. For goods besides transportation equipment, a less volatile measure, orders rose 0.3 percent in September after rising 1.2 percent in August. 
The Federal Reserve's ''beige book'' survey, published last week, found evidence that the cost of fuel held back consumer and business purchases in September and early October. Orders for equipment rose in September, today's report showed, suggesting companies were still investing inproductioncapacity even as other spending may have cooled.
 ''The key still is that there's strong capital goods orders in these numbers, which may still be a rush to buy equipment ahead of the expiration of tax incentives,'' said Avery Shenfeld, an economist with CIBC World Markets in Toronto. 
 Hurricanes also delayed shipments of goods, causing orders to fall, economists said.
 A report yesterday from the Institute for Supply Management found that services, the largest share of the economy, at 85 percent, expanded at an accelerated pace in October. The group's index jumped to 59.8 from 56.7; a reading higher than 50 indicates expansion. Services have been expanding since March 2003. 
 The back-to-back declines in factory orders, which brought them to $368.3 billion, were the first since November and December of 2002. Economists expected orders to rise 0.4 percent, the median of 58 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. 
 Through September, factory orders were up 11.6 percent for the year compared with theperiod in 2003, the Commerce Department said.

SECTION: Section B; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk; The Neediest Cases; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: He Gave Her His Kidney, And Also Stole Her Heart

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM

 BODY:
Aurelia Dawson-Alleyne should have met the tall man with the dreadlocks in her native country, Belize, where the Caribbean Sea inspires romance and the warm, wet air feels full of possibility. But as Ms. Dawson-Alleyne found, you cannot choose the setting of your love story. 
 This one begins with a premonition. 
 ''I have this type of gift,'' Ms. Dawson-Alleyne, 33, said. ''I know things ahead of time.'' 
 She was 14 years old, relaxing on a porch in Belize City, Belize, when she suddenly knew that one day, there would be a problem with her kidneys. She does not wonder how she knew. She believes in powers greater than herself. 
 Her first husband used to call her Prophetess. Ms. Dawson-Alleyne was pregnant with their third daughter when the marriage collapsed. 
 Devastated, Ms. Dawson-Alleyne moved out and took a job at a restaurant to support herself and her children. A year later, in 1994, her body began breaking down. 
 Some days she would vomit; other days she had diarrhea. Her breath was redolent of ammonia. Still, she continued to work. 
 It was not until 1995, when the entire right side of her body suddenly stiffened, that she went to a hospital.
 There, she found that her premonition had become a reality. Doctors discovered that Ms. Dawson-Alleyne had been born with only one kidney and made a diagnosis of end-stage renal disease. She was flown to a better-equipped hospital in Mexico, where she was told that she was close to death. 
 Ms. Dawson-Alleyne was indignant. ''My dad, he always told me, never give up,'' she said. ''Never think anything is impossible.''
 And so Ms. Dawson-Alleyne, who was too ill to speak, scrawled, ''Please try anything,'' on a slip of paper, and handed it to a doctor. 
 He performed dialysis without a machine, draining fluid from Ms. Dawson-Alleyne's body through a tube inserted in a slit just below her navel.
 The procedure saved her life, but at a cost: thereafter, she would have to live near a dialysis center. That meant coming to the United States and leaving her two oldest daughters in Belize. 
 She did not know then that one day, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund would help pay the immigration fees for those daughters to move to the United States. 
 Ms. Dawson-Alleyne moved to Harlem with her baby, Samantha, in 1995, where she spent 12 hours hooked up to a dialysis machine and the other 12 working as a cashier for $5 an hour. This routine was interrupted only when she was hospitalized for infections. Her skin is dappled with scars, reminders of what she says happened for a reason: to strengthen her. 
 ''I love that chapter in the Bible, the Book of Job,'' Ms. Dawson-Alleyne said. 
 Her next chapter, however, was more like the Song of Songs.
 She was in a treatment room at the Life Care Dialysis Center in Manhattan in 1998 when a technician called Adrian Alleyne introduced himself. It was not love at first sight. 
 She did not like his dreadlocks. But over time she fell for Mr. Alleyne. 
 One day she told him, ''I have a crush on you.''
 ''I have a girlfriend,'' Mr. Alleyne replied shyly.
 They became friends instead, watching the Discovery Channel during her thrice-weekly dialysis and going out for hot chocolate. 
 Ms. Dawson-Alleyne said that she grinned like a Cheshire cat whenever Mr. Alleyne was around. And like the cat in ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' Mr. Alleyne's girlfriend soon disappeared. 
 About five months into their relationship, Mr. Alleyne told Ms. Dawson-Alleyne that he wanted to give her one of his kidneys.
 ''I was shocked,'' she said. 
 After much consideration, she accepted his offer and underwent a successful kidney transplant in 1999. ''We're a perfect match,'' Mr. Alleyne told her. They married in 2002, two years after her daughters, Stephanie, now 13, and Sheryl, now 17, came to live with them. Samantha is 10 years old.
 The only damper on the reunion was the $2,640 in immigration fees that the family owed. 
 Ms. Dawson-Alleyne is presently unemployed and looking for work. Mr. Alleyne is a computer technician, but he is a temporary worker and receives no health benefits.
 Ms. Dawson-Alleyne went in search of assistance on the Internet, where she found Catholic Charities, Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven local charities supported by the Neediest Cases.
 She hoped that Catholic Charities would provide her with food stamps so that she could save money and pay the immigration fees. But she never dreamed that she would actually receive help paying those fees from the Neediest Cases, which provided the Alleynes with $1,320 -- half of what they owed. 
 Raising the other half is especially important to Ms. Dawson-Alleyne, who wants her daughters to attend college. It is how she envisions their futures. The Prophetess failed, however, to forecast something in her own life: she never thought that she would become the caretaker of her husband's dreadlocks which, through the years, have inched slowly down his back, measuring the length of their love story.

HOW TO HELP

Checks payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund should be sent to 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11245, or any of these organizations:

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section F; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1876 words

HEADLINE: The Address Says Rockefeller, But the School Says No

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. 

 BODY:
WHEN Leeann and Nick Cerrito went house hunting, they used the common calculus that drives such decisions in the suburbs: the quality of education, the value of real estate and the ways the two are inextricably bound.
 The first step was choosing the best schools for their children, Sophia, 7, Carson, 5, and Lila, 6 months. The second was finding the most house their money could buy, which depended not only on its price but also on real estate taxes, mortgage rates and the value of their Upper East Side apartment.
 After two years of looking, the Cerritos thought they had hit the jackpot.
 They picked the coveted Pocantico Hills school district, desirable not only for its test scores and small classes but for having the lowest taxes in Westchester County, an enviable anomaly resulting from Rockefeller landholdings there. Then they settled on a custom-built home on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River, which would have been unaffordable in a high-tax district. 
 ''You couldn't find a better set of circumstances,'' said Robert W. Balog, a member of the Pocantico Hills Board of Education and a property assessor by profession. ''That's why my family moved here. It's the best deal around.''
 It would have been the best deal around if the Cerritos and nine other families who were buying in the same development had not discovered, after signing contracts for houses costing $1.5 million to $2.9 million, that they might not be in the Pocantico Hills district after all, but rather in neighboring Tarrytown.
 That is Tarrytown's claim, and Pocantico Hills has joined the adjacent district in a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in White Plains that pits the developer and the prospective homeowners against the two school districts, and also in administrative proceedings before the State Education Department. A ruling from the court is expected by Nov. 5. But appeals are likely, and Albany could challenge the court's jurisdiction.
 ''This is not what we bargained for,'' said Mr. Cerrito, a lawyer. It was a careful understatement that did not disguise his anger and frustration.
 ''All I wanted was to drink my coffee on the patio and watch my kids play,'' Leeann Cerrito said. ''I had no plans to be the Norma Rae of Westchester.''
 The Cerrito family, awaiting resolution of the case, is currently crammed into a two-bedroom cooperative apartment. The baby is in the master bedroom, and the living room is clogged with bicycles. The older children are back in private school.
 The Cerritos recently sold their apartment for less than they would have gotten last spring, when the market was more robust. They will shortly move into a bigger rental apartment, which will cost triple what they are paying now. If interest rates climb, the jumbo mortgage for the new house will be more expensive.
 Tarrytown, with its bustling commercial strip, is a far cry from the bucolic Pocantico Hills district, not that these families thought they were choosing between the two. ''Our choice wasn't Pocantico versus Tarrytown,'' Mr. Cerrito said. ''It was Pocantico versus every other district in the area.''
 Cindy Kief, one of the home buyers and herself a real estate agent, said every client who walks into her office chooses where to live after asking two questions: ''What about the schools?'' and ''Is there a house I can afford?'' Ms. Kief sees this as perfectly reasonable. ''We have the right to decide where we want to live, in what house and in which school district,'' she said.
 The attractions of Pocantico, home to the Rockefeller family since the 19th century and beneficiary of its largess, are obvious.
 The quaint Tudor schoolhouse was built by the Rockefellers in 1932, for prekindergarten to eighth grade only, with an Olympic-size swimming pool, lighted tennis courts and a vast nature preserve at its backdoors. There is no commerce in the hamlet, just a historic church, a firehouse, the school and 900 acres of woodland, horse trails, pastures and streams, all deeded to the state by the Rockefellers.
 Revenue from the Rockefellers' holdings lifts the tax burden on others. Homes in the district are taxed $379.40 for each $1,000 in assessed value, which would come to $11,500 to $22,000 a year for those in the new development if they are determined to be in Pocantico Hills. The district is by far the smallest in the county, with 330 students, 83 percent of them white. Per-pupil expenditures are more than $20,000 a year.
 Tarrytown, by contrast, has a tax rate of $986.44 per $1,000, nearly three times as high, and the same houses there would yield $22,500 to $50,000 each in annual school taxes. Tarrytown has 2,350 students, more than half of them members of minorities. The district spends $15,000 a year per pupil.
 The disputed land was passed back and forth between the two school districts several times in the early 1950's, as Tarrytown sought voter approval to build a new high school. When a bond issue passed, part of the land was used for that purpose. The rest, as far as anyone knew, was returned to Pocantico. Since then, all property taxes have been paid to Pocantico.
 When the developer, Mitchell C. Hochberg of Spectrum Communities, bought the land, the first step was to establish that it was in the school district. Spectrum checked tax records, title reports and appraisals and spoke with the superintendent at the time, Peter M. Lisi, who later gave sworn testimony that the new houses were in the Pocantico district. Spectrum named the new enclave the Legends of Pocantico Hills.
 But at the 11th hour, after 10 of 11 houses were already in contract, the Tarrytown district claimed the property. Tarrytown's tax base has eroded in recent years, and the new houses, under the higher tax rate, would bring in $400,000 a year for the district. The prospective buyers were aghast, not sure who was to blame.
 Spectrum took the dispute to the State Education Department, where the official with jurisdiction discovered that paperwork returning the land to Pocantico had never been filed with the state.
 In his ruling the education department official, Ronald L. Smalls, said that the ''intent and inferences'' of the two districts were not the issue. All that mattered was that ''no further boundary line alteration was entered or filed.'' The homes were in Tarrytown, even if on a technicality.
 At that point, with Spectrum insisting that the two districts formally adjust the boundary to meet the ''wholly justified expectations of the many innocent purchasers,'' the Pocantico Hills Board of Education joined forces with Tarrytown, explaining that it was required to honor Mr. Smalls's ruling.
 That was in March. Since then the families have been in limbo. Three of them, including Craig and Jessica Benson and their two children, have already settled into their new homes, fingers crossed. Others have decided to await the outcome elsewhere, like the Cerritos. A few are betwixt and between.
 The Bensons, both lawyers, moved in August with their children, Lucas, 5, and Noah, 3. Their house in White Plains was already sold, so where else could they go? With court intervention, Lucas is in kindergarten in Pocantico, which the judge considered the status quo until a final resolution.
 Mr. and Ms. Benson have frequent arguments about whether they did the right thing. The latest issue is window treatments. She does not want to buy them until she knows that Lucas can remain in school in Pocantico. He would probably take the chance now, as he did in lobbying to move in.
 Cindy and Steven Kief were on the fence until recently, when they listed their 1936 Mediterranean-style house in nearby Irvington. Everyone has a story, but none quite like theirs. The Kiefs, in addition to 18-month-old Anna, have twin 6-year-old sons, Jake and Jesse, who have multiple disabilities, including cerebral palsy and mental retardation. Neither can speak, both are in wheelchairs, and one is also blind.
 The family was not house hunting. But Ms. Kief said she looked at the development for a client and saw a chance to build a house with an elevator, making it unnecessary for her, her husband and the round-the-clock nurses to carry 60-pound children up stairs ever again. They will move into the house, which has all kinds of adaptations for their handicapped sons, in December.
 A ''for sale'' sign is on the Kiefs' lawn in Irvington, and the house is spruced up to sell. ''We hit the wall trying to take care of the kids here,'' Ms. Kief said. ''We can't live in limbo anymore. We have to trust this is going to go the way it should go.''
 The families have become friends during the long period of uncertainty. Ms. Kief and Ms. Cerrito talk frequently, sharing their worries and their choices in paint colors. Carson Cerrito thinks it is cool that Jake and Jesse Kief will have their own elevator and has asked to be the operator.
 But confusion breeds confusion, and many people here question Pocantico's motivation. What role, if any, did the enormous potential expense of educating the Kief children play in the district's decision to support Tarrytown? Each district has so far spent $150,000 in legal fees, according to documents received in response to a freedom of information request by Thacher Proffitt & Wood, the law firm representing the developer.
 One lawyer on the case said he heard another discussing the ''handicapped kids'' in the courthouse hallway. A homeowner in the development said she was shocked when someone in town, out of the blue, denied that the Kief children were the issue. Such vague remarks jelled when Charles S. Minton, president of the Pocantico Hills Board of Education, was asked at a recent meeting why the district was turning its back on the tax revenue for 11 houses when the number of school-age children, 13 at the moment, would not overcrowd the school.
 Mr. Minton replied it was not clear that the new revenue would actually be a benefit. His remark, he said later, had nothing to do with the Kief twins, who under federal law must be educated at the expense of their local district. Instead, he said, he was referring to a back-of-the-envelope calculation that at any given time the development could have enough school-age children to cost the district far more than the $150,000 a year in new taxes.
 Mr. Minton was quick to add that he was not speaking for the board, which had not used budget concerns to drive its decision. Rather he said that Pocantico does not have the authority to overrule the state education department.
 Only one of five board members, Mr. Balog, sided with the families on the disputed land. First, he said, the school financing system in New York State is built around the notion that an entire school district bears the cost of educating its children, not one house or block or neighborhood, and that expanding the tax base is always good in the long run. In addition, he said, it is the ''essence of America'' that people have the right to choose where to live and educate their children, as the Cerritos, Bensons and Kiefs did.
 Ms. Kief said she wondered what would happen if every suburban home buyer had to worry that he was not, in fact, in the school district he had chosen.
 ''There'd be anarchy,'' she said. ''There'd be rioting in the streets.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: LIVING IN LIMBO -- The Kiefs, right, bought in a Westchester development, center right, believing their children would attend a school, below left, built by the Rockefellers. But because of a dispute over district lines, they may end up at school in Tarrytown, bottom right. (Photographs by Paxton for The New York Times)(pg. F1)
NEWCOMERS -- The Bensons, right, do not know if their children will be schooled in bustling Tarrytown, top left, or in a school with a nature preserve at its backdoor, top right.
 IN SUSPENSE -- A house that may or may not be in the Pocantico Hills district. Buyers are awaiting resolution of the dispute. (Photographs by Paxton for The New York Times)

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk; SMALL BUSINESS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1401 words

HEADLINE: Uncle Sam Wants You (to Apply for a Grant)

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON

 BODY:
As just about every entrepreneur with a bright idea knows, it can be a long and painful journey from the time the light bulb goes on to the day the revenue starts rolling in. 
 And perhaps the most frustrating experience of building a start-up is the never-ending quest for financing. A business owner who hits up family, friends, wealthy investors, banks or venture capitalists is likely to discover that they open their wallets reluctantly and become impatient for results once they do hand over the cash.
 But for high-technology entrepreneurs, there is another source of financing that can be as generous as it is little known: grants from the federal government's Small Business Innovative Research Program.
 The biggest fund, by far, is run by the Defense Department, which parcels out some $1 billion a year to independent companies with fewer than 500 employees. The goal is to stimulate research into novel technologies that can benefit military operations, but with a twist. The department is not paying for exclusivity for the ideas it finances; rather, it wants those ideas to go commercial as quickly as possible to assure a stream of reliable and cost-effective suppliers. 
 Martin Klein is one of its emerging success stories -- at least that is what he hopes. A chemical engineer by training, Mr. Klein has spent 40 years in the battery and fuel-cell business. In 1970, he founded the Energy Research Corporation, since renamed Fuel Cell Energy Inc., and later sold his stake in it. Today, it employs 500 people.
 Then, in 1992, he founded Electro Energy Inc. to develop batteries for the military, and that same year submitted a proposal for a grant for research into what he calls a rechargeable bipolar nickel-metal-hydride battery. What sets it apart from traditional batteries, Mr. Klein says, is its design, which stacks thin flat wafer cells atop one another to improve the flow of current while taking up less space. His eventual aim, he says, is to produce a battery that is 30 percent smaller and cheaper than conventional batteries yet provides 50 percent more power.
 The Defense Department, which is always on the prowl for better batteries, particularly for its communications equipment and aircraft, liked his idea. It awarded him $50,000.
 Mr. Klein went to work in the basement of his Brookfield, Conn., home, hiring a part-time technician, putting up four workbenches to create a small laboratory and starting work on creating prototypes. Six months later, he presented his test data to the Defense Department and won $750,000 for a second phase of work. He then moved out of the basement and into an office park and hired two full-time technicians and a secretary.
 Mr. Klein, 68, said that small-business innovation funds are ''why we are here today,'' but it is not blind governmental largess that kept him and his firm going. When Congress created the program 20 years ago, it was purposely planned not as a handout, but for directed research that would turn into viable commercial products.
 The Defense Department says its main criterion for choosing recipients is their determination to become a commercial business, not just a research house. It also selects companies active in areas where there is an ''actual need,'' it says, notably improvements in aircraft, satellites, military hardware, communications systems and logistical systems. 
 ''It's paramount that we have a feel for where they are going,'' said Dean Hudson, program manager for the Army Research Laboratory, one of the Defense Department agencies that reviews research applications from entrepreneurs. ''We evaluate their commercial market potential from the very beginning.''
 A handful of other government agencies have similar programs, including the National Institutes of Health, which has a $574 million annual budget and is the largest small-business innovation program after the Defense Department's. The Environmental Protection Agency, the National Science Foundation and the Departments of Energy, Commerce, Health and Human Services, Education and Agriculture have much smaller programs. Like the Defense Department's programs, they are based on a fixed percentage of their annual outside research budgets and thus the amounts vary year to year. All told, the agencies award about $2 billion annually.
 The departments and agencies once sent around ''idea books'' seeking high-tech innovators who could address the biggest needs. Now the information is posted on Web sites. Typically, one in eight bidders wins a Phase 1 contract from the Defense Department, and one in three of those wins the deeper-pocket Phase 2 funding. And entrepreneurs can keep going back for more.
 So, what does the Defense Department get out of its investment? It has landed some high-profile products; for example, Savi Technology Inc. of California developed a radio computer tag that could be attached to military cargo containers to track their location and contents.
 The SaviTag took $2.5 million, or three awards, of small-business innovation money before it went into production. The military is using it in Bosnia and other locations. Commercially, the tag is being used in the trucking, rail and shipping industries, bringing in some $20 million annually in revenue. 
 Another West Coast company, Silicon Designs Inc., developed the ''accelerometer,'' a sensor that tells a missile to arm itself when it reaches a specified acceleration. For its $1.2 million investment, the Defense Department got a replacement for a mechanical switch used in earlier missile systems that was less reliable and five times as expensive.
 The accelerometer is now being put in American-made Ford and Chrysler automobiles to cause air bags to inflate when a car decelerates abruptly during an accident. This commercial application is earning Silicon Designs some $40 million a year.
 Sometimes, the Defense Department also seeks out people to pursue commercial applications of technology it owns. That is what happened to Peter Amico, president of Airtrax Inc., when the Navy transferred its omnidirectional technology to his company in 1996. With an infusion of $850,000 in innovation research money, the company, based in Hammonton, N.J., invented a wheel that can turn in any direction: forward, laterally, diagonally and rotationally. 
 The Navy will be using Airtrax's forklifts and other lifts to reduce the amount of manpower needed to move objects. Mr. Amico said that Airtrax was now moving ahead to sell its Sidewinder omnidirectional lift trucks commercially to reap some profit from its years of research and development. 
 In Mr. Klein's case, the Defense Department ''got a battery that it didn't have that meets its needs,'' a spokeswoman said, ''and when the product is commercialized, it gets the economies of scale of a mass-produced product -- faster, cheaper and better.''
 It has been a long slog for Mr. Klein and others, who typically, according to the Defense Department, underestimate the time between developing a prototype and mass-producing a product.
 Mr. Klein went back to the Defense Department more than a dozen times for money, winding up with $5 million. He also got some grants from the Energy Department and landed some regular government contracts, raising a total of $18 million over the last dozen years.
 It was not easy. ''We had to replay the whole song each time we asked for money,'' he said. ''You can't count on anything coming through automatically.'' Going back for multiple grants is not unusual, the Defense Department says, as taking a high-technology product from the idea stage to the market can require 8 to 10 years.
 Mr. Klein's company, based in Danbury, Conn., projects $7 million in sales of test units to the military this year. It is starting a major advertising campaign to open the way for commercial use of its battery, including hybrid electric cars, electric bicycles and scooters and cordless power tools and laptops.
 Mr. Klein has rivals -- Panasonic in the electric-car market and Sanyo in the power tool market -- but he is confident about his business's future, he says, ''because we have a better mousetrap.''
 Today, his company has a stock market value of $100 million, he said, ''but none of the money has created anything in my pocket.'' Still, he is confident about the future, he said, ''because everyone wants a battery that is smaller, lighter and runs longer.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Martin Klein founded Electro Energy to develop batteries for the military. His aim, he says, is to make a smaller battery with more power. (Photo by Douglas Healey for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SUBJECT: ENTREPRENEURSHIP (91%); SMALL BUSINESS (90%); SCIENCE NEWS (90%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (90%); FUEL CELL TECHNOLOGY (89%); GRANTS & GIFTS (88%); VENTURE CAPITAL (78%); SMALL BUSINESS ASSISTANCE (77%); RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT (77%); ENGINEERING (77%); GOVERNMENT RESEARCH FUNDING (75%); ENERGY RESEARCH (74%); ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS (74%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (74%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (71%); SMALL BUSINESS CONTRACTING (69%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (69%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT (64%) Small Business; Research; Computers and the Internet; Entrepreneurship; Small Business

COMPANY: ELECTRO ENERGY INC (84%); FUELCELL ENERGY INC (54%)

ORGANIZATION: NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH (59%) Defense Department; National Institutes of Health

TICKER: FCEL (NASDAQ) (54%)

PERSON: Elizabeth Olson

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 4, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Economic Scene; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1063 words

HEADLINE: Why are Americans so divided over religious issues? Maybe it's those extreme messages.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel. 
Virginia Postrel (www.dynamist.com) is the author of '''The Substance of Style: How the Rise of Aesthetic Value Is Remaking Commerce, Culture and Consciousness,'' just published in paperback by Perennial.

 BODY:
HAVE religious issues become more important in politics because too few Americans go to church? 
 That is the surprising suggestion of a new working paper by the Harvard economist Edward L. Glaeser and two doctoral students, Jesse M. Shapiro and Giacomo A.M. Ponzetto. (The paper, ''Strategic Extremism: Why Republicans and Democrats Divide on Religious Values,'' is online at http://post.economics.harvard.edu/faculty/glaeser/papers.html.)
 The paper starts with a puzzle: In a majoritarian system like ours, political economists generally predict that candidates will converge toward the center of the spectrum, so as to attract as many votes as possible. This is the ''median voter theory.'' But it doesn't seem to describe what's happened in American politics. On divisive religious issues like abortion, the two parties aren't hugging the center. They're abandoning it.
 While most people know that the Republican Party has taken an increasingly strong anti-abortion position, the authors note that the Democratic Party has simultaneously moved in the opposite direction.
 In 1976, the Democratic platform said, ''We fully recognize the religious and ethical nature of the concerns which many Americans have on the subject of abortion,'' while terming a constitutional amendment overturning Roe v. Wade merely ''undesirable.'' In this year's platform, by contrast, Democrats declared that they ''stand proudly'' for a woman's right to an abortion, ''regardless of her ability to pay.''
 Conventional theory doesn't explain this shift. Even if voters were getting more religiously polarized -- splitting into secular and fundamentalist camps -- candidates would still have an incentive to split the difference.
 ''If some people are religious and some not, and voters simply choose the politician with views closest to their own, then a right-wing politician would want to take a stand on religious matters that is only just barely to the right of his opponent's position,'' Mr. Shapiro explained in an e-mail message. ''That way, he captures the entire religious vote, but also avoids leaving the middle ground open for his opponent to invade.''
 So what's going on?
 The economists propose a two-part answer.
 First, there are actually two important voting decisions -- not just whom to pick but whether to vote at all. Candidates need to get their voters excited enough to come to the polls (or possibly to give money). Extreme positions can do that.
 But positions that energize your base may also encourage the opposition to come out against you. That's where the second part of the model comes in. Candidates need a way to target their messages so their supporters are more likely to respond than their opponents.
 That's where social groups like churches and unions come in. These groups provide friendly forums for candidates' direct or indirect messages. While outsiders may know something about a candidate's more extreme positions, group members know more -- because the messages are aimed specifically at them.
 ''When I go out and say, 'I want to tax all the rich and I want to end outsourcing,' I can give that message to an economically left-wing audience without the economically right-wing audience hearing it with exactly the same probability,'' Professor Glaeser said. ''All you need is some ability to target your message, and then you're going to go to extremes.''
 Those in-group forums work, however, only if the groups are just the right size. They have to be small enough to be homogeneous and big enough to be influential. ''The model has this very odd prediction that the power of social groups is most when they're roughly 50 percent of the population,'' Professor Glaeser said.
 If a group is too small, it's not worth courting. But if it's too big, it includes too many of your opponent's supporters, making targeted messages impossible. If everybody goes to church or belongs to a union, membership in either group will not predict voting behavior.
 ''This is exactly what you see in the data,'' Professor Glaeser said. ''The degree of polarization around religious issues is greatest in the places that are in the middle. It's not the Philippines, which are 100 percent religious, and not Scandinavia, where no one has attended a church in 40 years except for a wedding or a funeral. It's really these places like the U.S. that are in the middle.''
 Similarly, in states like South Carolina where most people go to church regularly, whether someone attends church does not predict how he or she will vote.
 During the period studied, about 62 percent of South Carolina voters attended church at least once a month, but the churchgoers were only 4 percent more likely to vote Republican. In California, by contrast, only 38 percent reported monthly church attendance, and they were about 11 percent more likely to vote Republican.
 The same is true for changing church attendance over time. In the 1970's, 57 percent of Minnesotans attended church at least monthly, and churchgoers and nonchurchgoers split their votes about the same way. By the 1990's, only about 45 percent of Minnesotans were regular churchgoers. About 40 percent of them voted Republican, versus 23 percent of nonchurchgoers.
 Over the past several decades, the nation's church attendance has shrunk to the political sweet spot, while union membership has become too rare to reward sharp tilts to the economic left. Political platforms have diverged on religious issues and converged on economic issues.
 Yet abortion rates show no significant change with the party in office, while tax rates rise significantly under Democrats -- the opposite of what the political rhetoric promises. This result suggests that politicians move away from the social center mostly to get votes (''strategic extremism'') and diverge from the economic center because they actually prefer those policies (''nonstrategic extremism'').
 Since the success of extreme messages depends on keeping your supporters better informed than your opponents, the model suggests that changing news media could be as important as changing social groupings.
 ''If every time you say something in private to a religious group or a feminist group, it ends up on Drudge within three minutes in screaming headlines,'' Professor Glaeser said. ''It's going to stop people from going to extremes.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Will its members' regular attendance at this church in Newport Beach, Calif., affect their votes? (Photo by J. Emilio Flores for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Jets May Sell Rights to Seats, Then Tickets To Sit in Them

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Jets fans had better hold on to their seats.
 With the team planning to build what would easily be the most expensive stadium in the National Football League, the Jets are looking for new ways to raise money to pay for it.
 Many fans already expect ticket prices to go up when and if the proposed $1.4 billion stadium opens on the West Side of Manhattan. And the team has said the cost of luxury boxes would double, to more than $200,000 a year. But now the Jets are seriously considering something that would be new to the New York area: personal seat licenses. 
 That would mean that the Jets' 20,000 season-ticket holders would have to pay a one-time fee that could range from $250 a seat to $10,000 for the license, or guaranteed right, to buy season tickets. The tickets now cost an average of $720 a season. That does not include the $15 parking fee, hot dogs, beer or a team jersey.
 The team has not made a final decision and declined to discuss how much it would charge or how many seats would be licensed. But state officials say the Jets are now exploring seat licenses as a hedge against the rising cost of the project. 
 ''We remain committed to keeping the experience as affordable as possible,'' said Matthew Higgins, a Jets vice president.
 He said the use of seat licenses would be determined by how well the ''corporate market'' responded to the sale of luxury boxes, naming rights and advertising. 
 Team owners across the country have increasingly used the licenses as a way of raising cash to cover construction costs as public subsidies have declined. But even L. Jay Cross, the Jets' president, acknowledged that they have not been popular with fans.
 Fans in Chicago got angry a couple years ago when their beloved Bears sold licenses for 45 percent of the stadium's 61,000 seats to raise about $70 million for the $600 million renovation of Soldier Field. Depending on the location of the seats, the licenses cost $900 to $10,000. 
 ''It's certainly something that fans don't like to hear,'' said Rob Bressler, editor of Inside the Ownership of Pro Sports Teams. ''They generally don't like the idea of being charged a user's fee for a seat you have to buy anyway. But that's the way it is in today's N.F.L. economy.''
 The Jets are not alone in considering seat licenses. The New York area is undergoing a $5 billion sports construction frenzy, with the Jets, Yankees, Nets, Giants, Mets, Islanders, Devils, Rangers and Knicks all planning to build or renovate their stadiums or arenas. 
 The new owners of the Nets are also likely to require seat licenses for their proposed $435 million, 19,000-seat arena in Brooklyn.
 But the Jets' project -- a $1.4 billion, 75,000-seat stadium with a retractable roof -- is in another financial universe. Under the proposal, the city and state would contribute $300 million each, while the team would put up $800 million and cover any cost overruns. 
 The project was scheduled to go before the Empire State Development Corporation today for approval. Documents indicate that if the Jets decided to use seat licenses, the state would sell them tax-free and put the money toward cost overruns.
 ''Inevitably, there are complaints,'' said Marc Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Ltd. in Chicago, a sports and stadium consultant, ''but it should go relatively smoothly. In Chicago, there was some sticker shock. But people in New York are more sophisticated. They know that if you want great seats you have to pay for them.''
 Seat licenses are a product of the popularity of the team and the depth of the market, Mr. Ganis said. The Jets sell out every year, and there is a long list of people waiting for the opportunity to buy season tickets. The team recently charged a $50 fee just to be on the list. 
 Just as New York teams are considering seat licenses for new projects, they are also looking to build more high-priced luxury boxes to increase revenues. The Giants may increase the number of boxes at their home in the Meadowlands to about 130, from 117. The Nets are planning more than 125 luxury suites at their Brooklyn arena, and the Jets have designed a stadium with 240.
 But the owners of Madison Square Garden, where a $300 million renovation is planned, are worried that all those new suites would be more luxury than the market could bear. And so are the Yankees, who have proposed a new $750 million stadium in the Bronx. The team had initially wanted to build about 100 boxes, up from the current 18, but it has now cut back to 50 or 60.
 Mr. Ganis, however, thinks that there is nothing like the New York market.
 ''You're likely to have 900 or so luxury suites come on the market within a relatively short period of time,'' he said. ''But if there's any market in the country that could support them, it's New York. That doesn't mean there won't be some pricing pressure on the teams. But I believe the suites will get absorbed.''

HEADLINE: Russians and Britons Battle Over Vodka

BYLINE: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

 BODY:
A trademark dispute over a Russian vodka landed in the unlikeliest of places last week -- a federal court in Manhattan. Understanding how it got there takes some background in Balzac, a fondness for Russian conspiracy theories and a stiff shot of the stuff that started the fight.
 The battle's origins may seem remote. A company owned by Russia, the country, filed suit in Federal District Court last Thursday against several companies owned by Russians and a food distributor based in Britain, claiming it was the rightful owner of the trademark for Stolichnaya, more popularly known as Stoli. 
 But for New Yorkers with a fondness for nipping, the suit hits close to home. The British distributor, Allied Domecq, says it sells 20 million one-liter bottles of Stolichnaya annually in the United States, or about 120 million martinis' worth of one of this country's most popular vodkas. 
 This is the latest front in legal proceedings over the trademark that date back to its transfer from the Russian government more than a decade ago.
 In the suit, lawyers representing the state-owned company, whose name is a barely pronounceable Soviet-era moniker -- Soyuzplodoimport -- charge that the companies it is suing acquired the Stolichnaya trademark illegally. It was spirited away, the lawyers charged, after the Soviet Union broke apart in 1991.
 ''The trademark was unlawfully misappropriated when the Soviet Union broke up,'' said David Quinto, one of the lawyers. The suit is ''an effort to recover for Russia trademarks that are part of its national patrimony.'' 
 Allied Domecq, which bought the rights to the trademark in the United States in 2001 from Russian partners whose companies are registered in Cyprus and the Netherlands, said in a statement that they are ''incontestable'' and that it will ''vigorously defend'' them. A lawyer for the companies declined to comment.
 This case is typical of the economic confusion that ensued after the fall of the Soviet Union. Through a series of legal maneuvers, Soyuzplodoimport's state-appointed manager transformed it into a private firm, which he controlled, lawyers for the company say. The label, which was first registered in the 1960's and is to Russia what the hamburger is to America, later changed hands again.
 Then, in a smarting blow, production of the vodka was moved to Russia's sometimes bristly Baltic neighbor Latvia, after legal battles between the Russian state and Russian businessmen who owned the trademark began in 2000.
 Lawyers for Russia invoked the 19th-century French writer Honore de Balzac to describe the process of state asset sales, saying wily managers had made off with valuable enterprises, while the weak state, working frantically to keep the economy afloat, was not looking.
 ''Russia's privatization process is perhaps the best modern example,'' they wrote of Balzac's observation that ''behind every great wealth there is a crime.''
 They also employed a flow chart in the suit to show the complicated ownership transfers.
 Whether crime or legal purchase (and in Russia in the 1990's, the line between them was quite fine), both sides launched a flurry of legal proceedings. 
 Both pointed to Russian court rulings in their favor. The battle spilled over into other countries. It has been heard in a court in the Netherlands, where one of the companies is registered. 
 The bickering went further. Companies that the Russian government is now suing claimed to have a letter from a Russian deputy minister verifying the purchase as legal, but lawyers for the state argued that the letter and its letterhead were fake. 
 The companies have said they had nothing to hide, and they did not even bother changing the company's name, dropping only one of the O's to make it Soyuzplodimport. 
 Deeper into the suit, the accusations get darker. One of the companies was registered using the lost passport of an alcoholic woman, lawyers claimed. One of the Russian owners was accused by relatives of a dead business rival of poisoning him, lawyers for the government said. 
 It is still not clear whether the suit will proceed in the American courts, and what the effect would be on drinkers if it did. Would the vodka have a different taste if the Russian state took back production? What about an interruption in the supply?
 Jake Pendleton, a bartender at Zablozki's, a bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was not worried. ''There's no shortage,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Ford and G.M. Lose Ground to Imports

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
General Motors and the Ford Motor Company continued to lose ground to import brands last month, despite heavy levels of incentive spending, according to sales results released Wednesday. The numbers show that Chrysler is the only Big Three automaker on course to retain market share this year.
 Sales growth continued to slow for the largest sport utility vehicles, but large pickup trucks continued to gain market share. Over all, auto sales rose 2.2 percent last month over October 2003, to a strong seasonally adjusted sales rate of 16.9 million cars and trucks, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. 
 ''We are seeing demand and sales hold up better than some people expected,'' said Paul Ballew, the chief industry sales analyst at G.M., referring to industrywide sales. But he still saw room for improvement. At G.M., he said, ''As we look at our performance through 10 months, we're still not where we would like or expect to be.'' 
 Sales declined about 5 percent last month at G.M., the nation's largest automaker, and Ford, the second-largest. Consumers continued to leave G.M. and Ford, even though American automakers spent much more on incentives than companies like Toyota Motor and Honda Motor. 
 Automakers are spending more on rebates and other enticements for the biggest S.U.V.'s than for any other vehicles, according to the most recent data from Edmunds.com. And yet market share for those S.U.V.'s has been tailing off.
 Last month, large sport utilities were 5.9 percent of the auto market, down from 6.4 percent a year earlier, according to Ward's. 
 ''Even with strong customer incentives increased, truck-based S.U.V.'s were down 5.1 percent over last year's October performance,'' said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. ''Sales of these vehicles are likely to be essentially flat for the entire year.'' Much of that is tied to the industry's transition to lighter-weight sport utility vehicles, called crossovers, which combine features of cars and sport utilities, he said. There is a debate in the industry over the role of volatile gas prices in the sales decline for large S.U.V.'s.
 Analysts and economists said strong auto sales had been helped by incentive spending but that future results would be tied to oil prices and the progress of economic recovery. 
 ''The wild card will be energy prices,'' said David Littmann, senior economist at Comerica Bank, who expects them to decline. ''I think consumers will be bolstered by the fourth consecutive year of expansion, not wildly but steadily.''
 Jarlath Costello, Ford's chief economist, said, ''We will be looking at energy prices and job growth as important factors determining the outlook.''
 ''Despite high oil prices and tepid job growth, consumer spending was remarkably resilient in the third quarter, growing at an annual rate of 4.6 percent,'' he added. ''However, household income grew by just 1.4 percent. On this basis, it is fair to say that the spending pace of the last few months is unlikely to be sustained unless we see improvement in the labor market and some stability in oil prices.''
 Officials at Ford said they hoped that a new wave of products, including a redesigned Mustang and a large sedan called the Ford 500, would increase sales.
 ''We're very encouraged by the early dealer and consumer response to our new products,'' said Jim O'Connor, Ford's group vice president of North American sales, service and marketing. ''We have our sights set on stronger retail sales in the months ahead.'' 
 David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities, said, ''The Big Three had a terrible month. Only Chrysler was able to have a gain and maintain their market share.'' 
 Sales at Chrysler, buoyed this year by a revamped product lineup, were up 2.3 percent. The automaker's new Chrysler 300C sedan has been a rarity among American sedans -- it is a talked-about car that appears in rap videos and is hard to miss on the road. On the other hand, the company has a large inventory of unsold vehicles, a concern to some analysts. 
 Toyota Motor sales rose 13 percent last month, and the company supplanted Chrysler as the third-largest auto seller in the United States. Toyota still ranks behind Chrysler's parent, DaimlerChrysler, which includes Mercedes-Benz, and is behind Chrysler for the year. 
 Will the Big Three soon include Toyota?
 ''I don't think they'll do it for the year, but I wonder about that comparison next year,'' Mr. Healy said.
 Not all import brands are flying off dealer lots. A new package of warranty and service offers made by Mitsubishi does not appear to have helped the struggling brand's sales, down 43.7 percent, from continuing their collapse. The company has grappled this year with a series of financial setbacks and scandals.
