Correction Appended 
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: A LOOK BACK -- THE CAMPAIGN; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2051 words

HEADLINE: Turnout Effort and Kerry, Too, Were G.O.P.'s Keys to Victory

BYLINE: This article was reported by Elisabeth Bumiller, David M. Halbfinger and David E. Rosenbaum and written by Ms. Bumiller.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
In the closing hours of President Bush's campaign for re-election, Karl Rove, his chief political adviser, was obsessed with turning out Republican votes. Late on Monday night, Mr. Rove stood in the cold at a rally in Albuquerque and pulled scraps of paper from his pocket covered with numbers that reassured him that his ground army was in full assault.
 ''In Nevada, where last time there were 598,000 votes cast, our organization made 130,000 contacts,'' Mr. Rove said, rattling off the statistics. ''That's 100,000 targeted phone calls and knocks on the door of 30,000 targeted households. These are less active Bush-oriented voters, people who have not had a pattern of voting, Democrats, Republicans and independents.''
 He had similar numbers for Florida, Pennsylvania and every other contested state, all part of his four-year effort to prod the Republicans into matching the high Democratic turnout in presidential elections. ''What we're trying to do is get our efforts up to parity,'' he said. 
 On Tuesday night, Mr. Rove succeeded, as Mr. Bush was re-elected with a margin of 3.5 million votes, in the first presidential election in modern history with an equal turnout of Democrats and Republicans. Mr. Rove's relentless focus on turning out more Republican voters, many of them evangelical Christians, was the critical factor in Mr. Bush's victory, Republicans said.
 Other factors, Republicans said, were Mr. Bush's gamble to run on terrorism and his repeated use of a clear, concise message. And Bush campaign officials said they were helped by the man they called a dream opponent, Senator John Kerry, whose nuanced statements about Iraq gave them an opening, day after day, to attack him as a ''flip-flopper.'' 
 Their high point, Bush campaign officials said, came in the spring, when Mr. Kerry uttered the now-famous line that he had voted for $87 billion for American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan before he voted against it.
 ''It was the most iconic moment of the campaign,'' said Mark McKinnon, the president's chief media strategist. ''As soon as we saw it, we knew that was exactly what we wanted to say, but he said it for us. That's something he couldn't undo.''
 But in Boston on the morning after Mr. Kerry's defeat, the harsh hindsight had begun. Despite the applause heaped upon his campaign manager, Mary Beth Cahill, some advisers were already pointing to what they called the major strategic errors of his campaign. All requested anonymity because they did not want to be seen as criticizing the candidate at a painful time.
 Kerry advisers cited the senator's lack of a clear and consistent message right up until mid-September, and suggested that his theme-of-the-week inconsistency and shifting attacks on the president in some ways bore out Mr. Bush's argument that Mr. Kerry was too indecisive and vacillating to lead the nation.
 Many advisers said Mr. Kerry's most obvious mistake was his long delay in responding forcefully to the attacks by members of the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, the group of Vietnam veterans who criticized Mr. Kerry in a best-selling book and television commercials as a liar, a traitor and a coward.
 But some of Mr. Kerry's most trusted friends and supporters said the delay on the Swift-boat issue only spotlighted a weakness in his campaign that had been apparent since Mr. Bush began labeling him as a flip-flopper in March, an accusation he never forcefully repulsed. ''They weren't prepared to defend his character,'' a longtime friend said. 
 But there were other major behind-the-scenes mistakes. Much as Mr. Kerry had proved a fearless gambler a year ago, mortgaging his house to finance his candidacy and staking his campaign on a come-from-behind victory in Iowa, his campaign against Mr. Bush was marked by moments of caution, some advisers said, like his decision to accept $75 million in public money for the fall campaign and the spending cap that came with it, rather than opting out and raising and spending as much as he could. 
 The practical effect was that Mr. Kerry's campaign could not afford to spend money on advertising in August, at the height of the Swift-boat group's attacks.
 Those who argued against opting out said Mr. Kerry would probably have had only $4 million to $5 million left after the Democratic convention. As it turned out, he had more than $45 million. 
 In the end, some of Mr. Kerry's longtime advisers asserted that his campaign and high-priced consultants had failed him in many ways, but that he had only himself to blame for the clutter of strategists, with no one clearly in charge, whose output was often late and not harnessed into an overall strategy.
 ''The campaign was never as good as the candidate,'' one old friend and strategist said. ''But that's also a reflection on the candidate.''
 Bush campaign officials said they had a candidate who was better than their campaign, which was in itself a tightly run, richly financed and highly disciplined message machine. And while Mr. Bush's advisers readily conceded that he fell short in the debates, on the stump in front of friendly Republicans Mr. Bush was a charismatic performer.
 ''We had at the top of the ticket an inspiring individual who knew what he believed and did what he said,'' Mr. Rove said Wednesday. ''At the end of the day, people voted for him for two reasons. One is they thought he could do the job, and two, they had deep doubts about the other guy.''
 Many of those voters, Mr. Rove said, were evangelical Christians, although he said he could not tell directly from polls of voters if evangelicals had turned out in greater numbers than they had in 2000. But there is some evidence that they did.
 Mr. Rove has long said that Mr. Bush lost the popular vote in 2000 in part because four million evangelicals stayed home, perhaps, he said, because of an old drunken driving charge against Mr. Bush that surfaced the weekend before the election and perhaps because many evangelicals traditionally viewed politics with distaste.
 But in this election, evangelicals said they were motivated to turn out because of Mr. Bush's support for a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, prompted by a decision a year ago by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court allowing such marriages in the state. In addition, Republicans said evangelical voters had an extra incentive because 11 states had amendments to ban same-sex marriage on the ballot.
 ''For the first time in our country's history, the definition of marriage has been changed by a court,'' said Tom Minnery, vice president of public policy at Focus on the Family, an influential conservative Christian group, in an interview on Wednesday. ''That was a wake-up call.''
 Mr. Minnery said that evangelicals turned out in large numbers for Mr. Bush in 2004 because they knew him better than they did in 2000 and recognized the biblical phrasing in many of his speeches. ''In his first term, he was the most openly Christian president we have had in our lifetime,'' Mr. Minnery said. ''And that endeared many Christian people to him.'''
 Republicans also said Mr. Bush won by broadening the reach of his party, much like Ronald Reagan did in the 1980's.
 ''He kept faith with every piece of the center-right coalition -- taxpayers, property owners, investors, businessmen, home-schoolers, gun owners and all communities of faith,'' said Grover Norquist, a leading conservative and the president of Americans for Tax Reform.
 Mr. Rove argued that rather than just playing hard to his Republican base, Mr. Bush's record total of 58 million votes, the most votes for any presidential candidate in history, proved that he had appealed well beyond his core conservative supporters to small-business people, families concerned about ''the coarseness of the culture,'' and ''security moms and dads'' worried about terrorism. 
 Significantly, polls on Election Day showed that the number of voters who said they were concerned about moral values -- who voted in overwhelming numbers for Mr. Bush -- was higher than those who said they were worried about the war, terrorism, the economy or jobs.
 Republicans also said that Mr. Bush won by running hard in the end in what Ken Mehlman, the president's campaign manager, called strong Republican ''fortress'' areas surrounded by rapidly growing suburbs and exurbs filled with first-time voters. 
 ''The thing that characterized the areas more than anything else was a growing propensity to vote Republican and a significant number of potentially unregistered supporters,'' Mr. Rove said.
 If Mr. Bush and Mr. Rove were determined from the first to get every last evangelical Christian to the polls, Mr. Kerry and his advisers seemed to respond only relatively late in the campaign to what polls eventually showed was his gaping weakness with voters on the question of whether a candidate shared their values.
 Campaign aides knew all along that Mr. Kerry, whose New England reticence held him back from discussing his religion, was at a steep disadvantage with Mr. Bush among regular churchgoers. But while he began over the summer sprinkling the word ''values'' into his speeches, it was mainly in saying that hard work should be rewarded, that the middle class and the poor should be given help before the rich got more.
 And while Mr. Bush could use code words like ''culture of life'' and ''armies of compassion'' to motivate evangelicals, Mr. Kerry found himself preaching the separation of church and state from pulpits. Late in the campaign, Mr. Kerry spent every weekend visiting churches, taking communion from Roman Catholic priests who welcomed him despite his support for abortion rights.
 Sam Greenberg, one of Mr. Kerry's pollsters, said the faith and values problem was ''consuming,'' and added: ''He was having immense difficulty breaking through. He's not as secular as he was defined, but that was not what he was able to communicate.'' 
 Mr. Kerry did not help himself in getting voters to see him as an ordinary guy when he was photographed windsurfing in August off his Nantucket home, or that he chose a resort to prepare for his first debate, while Mr. Bush was on his ranch, or that his wealthy wife spoke English with an unfamiliar accent and Mr. Kerry spent his childhood summers in France.
 ''People don't windsurf in Youngstown, Ohio,'' a longtime top Kerry adviser said. 
 There were also Mr. Kerry's swings and misses: calling the Green Bay Packers stadium Lambert Field, not Lambeau, and mangling the names even of his own beloved Red Sox.
 In candid moments, Mr. Kerry himself often said that, with war and terrorism occupying the nation, he did not think ''likeability'' would play as important a role in the campaign as it had in the 2000 election. But the longtime aide said that Mr. Kerry, as a challenger facing a well-known incumbent, had no margin of error in his efforts to connect with voters. ''It all goes into the pot,'' the aide said. 
 The values problem took on enormous significance, Kerry aides said, precisely because of the electoral terrain the campaign was fighting on, which they said posed a major challenge for Democrats in the future: how to talk to Americans in the heartland.
 ''We were working from a pretty small map here,'' said Steve Elmendorf, Mr. Kerry's deputy campaign manager. ''He was pressuring us much more in places where Gore had won than we were pressuring him where he had won, like New Hampshire and Nevada: those were only four electoral votes. He had us in New Mexico, Iowa, Wisconsin and Minnesota, and in Pennsylvania and Michigan we could never take our eye off the ball. 
 ''It wasn't a resource question so much as we weren't competitive in places like Missouri and Arkansas that Bush had won, so he was able to take enormous resources and really pour them into those states,'' Mr. Elmendorf said.
 Bill Carrick, a Democratic strategist, said the unfavorable electoral map meant Mr. Kerry had no obvious recipe for a victory, which explains why advisers experimented continually with positive and negative messages and with focusing more on domestic policy or national security.
 ''I've been in campaigns when you had a clear path to victory if you did one, two and three,'' Mr. Carrick said. ''Here, there was some message testing, because there was no clear path.''


CORRECTION-DATE: November 6, 2004

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Republican emphasis on turnout misstated the given name of a Kerry pollster who commented on the senator's difficulty in communicating his positions on faith and values. He is Stan Greenberg, not Sam. 
 Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to the area in Missouri on which politicians often focus as part of a strategy to win the state. It is the Missouri Bootheel, not hills.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the Republican emphasis on turnout referred incorrectly to the area in Missouri on which politicians often focus as part of a strategy to win the state. In some copies yesterday a correction in this space misspelled the name of that area. It is the Missouri Bootheel, not Boothill or hills.

PUB-DATE: November 4, 2004
Correction Appended 
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- Northeast; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 3556 words

HEADLINE: A near sweep for Senator Kerry in his home region.

BYLINE: Contributing to this report were Elissa Gootman, Patrick Healy, Michael Janofsky, Michael Luo, Jennifer Medina, Robert Pear, Richard Prez-Pea, Marc Santora, Stephanie Strom and Daniel J. Wakin.

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT -- KERRY
 It was a hair-raising evening for Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican who fended off sharp attacks by his Democratic opponent, Diane Farrell, the first selectwoman of Westport.
 Early results showed him trailing Ms. Farrell, who had tried to paint him as a conservative of the same ilk as Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority leader. But returns from Republican-leaning towns like Greenwich and Trumbull turned the tide.
 In his victory speech, Mr. Shays revealed that internal polls had shown him losing the race just two weeks before the election, which may explain why he was at Grand Central Terminal on Monday evening, greeting surprised commuters heading home to Fairfield County.
 While the Shays-Farrell race turned into an unexpectedly hot contest, the nasty House battle between Rob Simmons, the Republican incumbent, and Jim Sullivan, a former Norwich councilman, was more tepid than predicted. Mr. Simmons easily defeated Mr. Sullivan for eastern Connecticut's seat, thanks in part to help from the Republican National Congressional Committee, which underwrote a harsh advertising campaign.
 Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Democrat, won a fifth term, a first for a Connecticut senator. Mr. Dodd, 60, spent some $5million to defeat a Republican newcomer, Jack Orchulli, a former fashion industry executive who spent more than $1.3 million on his campaign.
 With the defeat of Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who is the Senate minority leader, Mr. Dodd is considered a leading contender for a top Senate leadership position. His name has also surfaced on lists of potential candidates for governor and president. 
 Senator Kerry won Connecticut's seven electoral votes, even though he, like President Bush, never campaigned in the state.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Kerry: 847,666 -- 54%
Bush: 686,923 -- 44%
Nader: 12,708 -- 1%

SENATE
100% reporting
Dodd: 923,836 -- 66%
Orchulli: 452,874 -- 32%

DELAWARE -- KERRY
 Senator Kerry won in Delaware, where Gov. Ruth Ann Minner, a Democrat, was elected to a second term. She defeated Bill Lee, a former Superior Court judge, who was the Republican candidate. 
 Ms. Minner and Mr. Lee sparred over the economy, the environment and education, in particular the state's testing program and an unusual three-tiered high school diploma system that has been put on hold. Perhaps the most contentious topic was the state's prison system, with the governor drawing criticism for her handling of a case in which a prison counselor was abducted and raped.
 Ms. Minner, a twice-widowed mother of three who left high school to help support her family but later went back for an equivalency degree, is the state's first female governor. In the end, she was able to win over voters, but the results were closer than early polls had suggested -- a fact that Mr. Lee mentioned in his concession speech. 
 Ms. Minner won with 51 percent of the vote to Mr. Lee's 46 percent, in the state's closest governor's race since 1972. 
 Delaware's lone member of the House, Representative Michael N. Castle, a Republican who is a former governor, was easily re-elected to a seventh term, beating Paul Donnelly, a Democrat.

95% reporting
Kerry: 191,870 -- 53%
Bush: 164,807 -- 46%
Nader: 2,050 -- 1%

GOVERNOR
95% reporting
Minner: 177,848 -- 51%
Lee: 160,215 -- 46%

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA -- KERRY
 Marion S. Barry Jr., the former mayor who was caught on tape by the F.B.I. smoking crack cocaine in 1990, resurrected his political career by winning a City Council seat. ''It's not a comeback,'' Mr. Barry told reporters at a victory party. ''It's a coming out of retirement.'' Mr. Barry, who won by a wide margin, will represent one of the district's poorest neighborhoods.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Kerry: 183,876 -- 90%
Bush: 19,007 -- 9%
Nader: 1,3181 -- %

MAINE -- KERRY
 Maine voters swung solidly behind Senator Kerry, a fellow New Englander, even though the Bush family has long had a home in the state. Maine is one of two states that can divide its electoral votes, but Mr. Kerry carried both Congressional districts and therefore won all four electoral votes. 
 The state's House members, both Democrats, were easily re-elected. Representative Tom Allen, whose district includes Portland and Augusta, won a fifth term, trouncing Charlie Summers, a former state senator. In the huge Second District, covering northern Maine, Representative Michael H. Michaud won a second term. 
 Two ballot propositions went down to defeat. A proposal to set a statewide limit on property taxes was overwhelmingly rejected, after state and local officials warned that it would force cuts in school budgets and municipal services. But Gov. John Baldacci, a Democrat, got the message and said he would offer a tax relief plan.
 Voters also rejected a proposal to outlaw the hunting of bears with bait, traps or dogs. Hunters and state officials opposed the ban, saying it would cause economic harm, while supporters ran television advertisements that portrayed bear hunting as cruel.

PRESIDENT
81% reporting
Kerry: 298,886 -- 53%
Bush: 251,274 -- 45%
Nader: 6,213 -- 1%

MARYLAND -- KERRY
 There were few surprises when the polls closed in Maryland. 
 Senator Kerry won the state by almost the same margin Vice President Al Gore had four years earlier. The popular Democratic Senator Barbara A. Mikulski was re-elected by a 30-point margin. And every incumbent in the House delegation won easy re-election.
 Ms. Mikulski said Tuesday night that her victory was proof that Maryland, despite electing a Republican governor in 2002, was still terra firma for Democrats. Her victory takes her to a fourth term.
 The race between Ms. Mikulski and her Republican challenger, E.J. Pipkin, often sounded like a page cribbed from the presidential campaign. Mr. Pipkin, who sunk $1 million of his own money into the campaign, attacked Ms. Mikulski for her votes to raise taxes and to oppose the Iraq war.
 Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore was re-elected with 88 percent of the vote, a win that sets him up for a run for governor in 2006. Mr. O'Malley, a Democrat, has built a reputation working to reduce crime and revive the city.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Kerry: 1,209,827 -- 56%
Bush: 936,505 -- 43%

SENATE
99% reporting
Mikulski: 1,368,267 -- 65%
Pipkin: 713,852 -- 34%

MASSACHUSETTS -- KERRY
 There were no surprises in Massachusetts, with Senator Kerry capturing 62 percent of the vote in his home state. The state's 10 representatives seeking re-election, Democrats one and all, also coasted to victory. Four ran unopposed. 
 For some Democratic politicians, there was a particularly personal dimension to the disappointment of President Bush's win.
 In the months leading up to the election, there had been much discussion of the special election that would have been held to fill Mr. Kerry's Senate seat, had he won the presidency. It would have been the state's first open Senate seat since 1984, when Mr. Kerry won the race to succeed the ailing Paul Tsongas. 
 Among those who had been talked about for the position were Representatives Barney Frank, Edward J. Markey and Martin T. Meehan.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Kerry: 1,793,647 -- 62%
Bush: 1,067,143 -- 37%

NEW HAMPSHIRE -- KERRY
 For the first time in nearly eight decades, a challenger unseated the incumbent candidate for governor, with John Lynch, a Democrat, getting 50.8 percent of the vote, less than 2 percent more than Gov. Craig Benson. The outcome was uncertain until early yesterday, long after it became clear that Senator Kerry had won the state. 
 Mr. Benson came into office two years ago, promising not to add or raise taxes. He kept the promise but was plagued by charges of cronyism, and several members of his staff resigned amid ethics scandals. The race had been just hairs apart in the polls for weeks, with the candidates relying heavily on money from their own pockets -- Mr. Lynch spending $1.3 million of his own and Mr. Benson $1.4 million. Mr. Benson, a businessman without much experience in government, said he would probably retire from politics. 
 Mr. Lynch was aided by a record voter turnout. New Hampshire had long been considered a battleground in the presidential campaign, and the theory was proved on Tuesday. Mr. Kerry won 50 percent of the vote, just 9,171 votes more than President Bush, who won 49 percent. Ralph Nader received 1 percent of the total.
 With nearly 680,000 votes cast, turnout beat the record of 578,000 set in 2000, when the state's four electoral votes went to Mr. Bush by a margin of one percentage point. Had Vice President Al Gore won in New Hampshire, he would have had the majority of electoral votes. 
 Voters who said they considered themselves moderate or independent supported Mr. Kerry by a margin of nearly two to one, according to surveys. The war in Iraq was clearly a major factor -- about half of the voters questioned said they disapproved of the war and nearly all of those gave their votes to Mr. Kerry. 
 Senator Judd Gregg, a Republican, got two-thirds of the vote and defeated the Democratic challenger, Doris Haddock, also known as Granny D. Ms. Haddock gained national attention in 1999 when she walked across the country to rally for campaign finance reform. 
 Representatives Jeb Bradley and Charles Bass, both Republicans, also kept their seats.

Kerry: 340,019 -- 50%
Bush: 330,848 -- 49%
Nader: 4,447 -- 1%

SENATE
100% reporting
Gregg: 434,292 -- 66%
Haddock: 221,011 -- 34%

NEW JERSEY -- KERRY
 Senator Kerry easily carried New Jersey, but President Bush received 300,000 more votes this year than he did in 2000. 
 Asked whom they would trust to handle the terrorist threat, voters were almost as likely to say Mr. Kerry as Mr. Bush. Only one-fourth of voters said that terrorism was the most important issue influencing how they voted.
 Nearly 700 New Jersey residents were killed in the attack on the World Trade Center, but Democrats said the state's voters did not accept the White House's contention that they were being protected from terrorism by the Bush administration.
 Mr. Bush outpolled Mr. Kerry among whites. In surveys of voters leaving the polls, black voters overwhelmingly favored Mr. Kerry, but more than one-third of Hispanics expressed support for Mr. Bush.
 Mr. Kerry did particularly well among first-time voters and those under 30.
 All 13 House members were re-elected.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Kerry: 1,799,320 -- 53%
Bush: 1,587,494 -- 46%
Nader: 18,614 -- 1%

NEW YORK -- KERRY

Even Senator Charles E. Schumer's most loyal partisans did not predict the magnitude of his re-election victory over Assemblyman Howard D. Mills, which set state records for most votes, highest percentage of the vote and largest winning margin.
 The victory by Mr. Schumer, a Democrat, was all the more striking in that Senator Kerry's victory here fell short of Al Gore's and Bill Clinton's margins in the state.
 The results will fuel the already widespread talk that Mr. Schumer might run for governor in 2006, talk he has done nothing to dampen. That could set up a fierce primary clash with another popular Democrat, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.
 ''Running up the score is a great send-off if you want to run for something else,'' said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College polls. ''Schumer comes out of this with great strength in every part of the state. Of all the Democrats around the country, he's in as good a position as anybody.''
 Another closely watched race in New York, to represent the Buffalo area in Congress, remained too close to call. With most votes counted, Assemblyman Brian Higgins, a Democrat, led Nancy Naples, the Republican Erie County comptroller, by less than 2 percent. Jack Quinn, a Republican, vacated the seat, giving Democrats one of their best chances nationally for a gain.
 Republicans held on to another open House seat, as State Senator Randy Kuhl defeated Samara Barend, a Democratic newcomer, to succeed Representative Amo Houghton, who is retiring. The race was roiled by the release of Mr. Kuhl's divorce records, which were supposed to be sealed. They included allegations that he had waved shotguns at his wife. The news backfired when it was revealed that it was Ms. Barend's campaign manager who had obtained the records from the court.
 All House members seeking re-election won handily. But several state legislators were defeated, an unusual turn in this state, as Democrats made gains in both houses. Challengers made inroads this year by calling incumbents part of a dysfunctional culture in Albany.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Kerry: 3,945,432 -- 58%
Bush: 2,763,506 -- 40%
Nader: 104,192 -- 2%

SENATE
99% reporting
Schumer: 4,368,286 -- 71%
Mills: 1,518,664 -- 25%

PENNSYLVANIA -- KERRY
 Throughout the campaign, Pennsylvania was a virtual home-away-from-home for President Bush and Senator Kerry as they spent considerable time and vast resources wooing a state they both argued was crucial for victory.
 While Mr. Bush did not win it (for the second time), Mr. Kerry might have conceded Tuesday night without it.
 Yet postelection surveys suggested that much of the candidates' efforts in the final weeks were superfluous, as nearly 80 percent of voters said they had made up their minds before the final month of the campaign.
 Mr. Kerry's success was built on the kind of solid calculation that eluded him elsewhere: he ran stronger than Mr. Bush among women, blacks and Hispanics, the youngest of voters, the oldest and large majorities who believed the economy was ''not so good'' or poor. He also ran much stronger in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh than in most other places in the state.
 But as a reflection of Mr. Bush's strength across the country and the central themes of his campaign, Mr. Kerry was not the choice of voters who said terrorism or moral values was the issue that most determined how they voted.
 Senator Arlen Specter, a moderate Republican who fended off a fierce primary challenge from a House conservative, waited out Representative Joe Hoeffel's early lead to overtake him in the late hours and win by 11 points (53 percent to 42 percent), securing a fifth term.
 ''This victory is an important symbol for the moderate wing of the Republican Party,'' Mr. Specter said in victory, a message as much for his supporters as for Senate conservatives, who outnumber those Republicans who sometimes vote with Democrats. 
 Two minor-party candidates shared the remaining 5 percent of the vote.
 Mr. Hoeffel, a three-term House Democrat, proved to be no match for Mr. Specter's deep familiarity among voters, as evidenced by the senator's winning 28 percent of the Democratic vote and scoring a two-point edge, 47 percent to 45 percent, among independents, according to voter surveys.
 Mr. Specter, who is 74, was also the clear choice among all voters over 29 years old and a majority of those with annual incomes above $30,000.
 Pennsylvania's House races provided a dash of drama but no seat changes. The state's three open seats were filled by candidates from the same party, and in a sign of the noncompetitive nature of most House races these days, two incumbents ran unopposed, and six others won with 86 percent of the vote or more.
 Only Jim Gerlach, a first-term Republican in a district east of Philadelphia, had to sweat out a challenge, hanging on to defeat a Democratic county attorney, Lois Murphy, by 51 percent to 49 percent.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Kerry: 2,870,358 -- 51%
Bush: 2,748,900 -- 49%

SENATE
99% reporting
Specter: 2,882,829 -- 53%
Hoeffel: 2,283,694 -- 42%

RHODE ISLAND -- KERRY
 Rhode Island and its four electoral votes stayed firmly in the New England pro-Kerry block. Senator Kerry won 60 percent of the vote to President Bush's 39 percent, with 1 percent going to Ralph Nader. Rhode Island has voted Democratic in every presidential race since 1984.
 Two Democratic Representatives, Jim Langevin and Patrick J. Kennedy, the youngest son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, easily defeated their Republican challengers. 
 Mr. Langevin won a third term and Mr. Kennedy a sixth, defeating a former Navy Seals member named Dave Rogers, who lost to Mr. Kennedy a second time in a row.
 The race was one of the 10 most expensive House elections, with the two campaigns raising a combined $3.8 million. But it was a less contentious race than the one two years ago. 
 ''I think that both of us were able to be very civil and give Rhode Islanders a clear choice,'' Mr. Rogers told The Associated Press on Election Day. Senator Kennedy campaigned for his son on Tuesday. Representative Kennedy, 37, entered politics at 21 by winning a seat in the State General Assembly. He has represented the state's First District for 10 years.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Kerry: 247,071 -- 60%
Bush: 161,345 -- 39%
Nader: 3,976 -- 1%

VERMONT -- KERRY
 Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican, was re-elected by a comfortable margin after a spirited contest with Peter Clavelle, the mayor of Burlington. 
 Keeping true to their reputation of refusing to rigidly toe any party line, Vermonters elected Democrats, Republicans and independents.
 As expected, Senator Kerry won the state convincingly, by roughly 20 percentage points. However, the turnout for him had virtually no impact on the race for governor, despite repeated attempts by Mr. Clavelle, a Democrat, to link Governor Douglas and President Bush and the war in Iraq. In the end, the governor won by a margin of 21 percentage points.
 Mr. Douglas acknowledged the vagaries of party affiliation in the state, telling supporters that he planned a ''mainstream'' and ''bipartisan'' administration.
 ''Vermonters appreciate the hard work we've done,'' he said in his victory speech. ''With the help of all of you in this room, I look forward to providing leadership to this state, helping all Vermonters fulfill the promise of Vermont." 
 The campaign, which featured a series of debates that provided a chance for voters to hear more than just clipped sound bites, offered a clear choice in governing ideologies. 
 Mr. Clavelle was, until recently, a member of the Progressive Party, which is more liberal than the Democrats on many issues. He changed party affiliation to run for governor but was nonetheless identified with the Progressive Party throughout the race.
 While Mr. Douglas mostly steered clear of direct criticism of his opponent, he did finance a series of ads that portrayed Mr. Clavelle as an out-of-the-mainstream tax-and-spend liberal.
 Mr. Douglas focused his campaign on a pro-business record, support for economic development and more funds for antidrug programs. He also showed that he was not afraid to break with the national Republican Party. For instance, he was harshly critical of the Bush administration's environmental record. That stance helped him fend off Mr. Clavelle's attempt to link him with Mr. Bush.
 In other contests, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat, easily won re-election, trouncing his Republican opponent, Jack McMullen, by 45 percentage points.
 Representative Bernard Sanders, the only independent in the House, also won an easy victory.

PRESIDENT
98% reporting
Kerry: 181,366 -- 59%
Bush: 119,110 -- 39%
Nader: 4,379 -- 1%

SENATE
98% reporting
Leahy: 207,266 -- 70%
McMullen: 72,737 -- 25%

GOVERNOR
98% reporting
Douglas: 179,032 -- 59%
Clavelle: 115,670 -- 38%

WEST VIRGINIA -- BUSH
 It was one of the states most visited by President Bush and Senator Kerry in the campaign, but West Virginia ended up being nothing close to a battleground, supporting Mr. Bush by a margin that would have been unimaginable when President Bill Clinton sailed to easy victories there in 1992 and 1996.
 Reflecting concerns over foreign attacks and jobs, nearly 30 percent of Democrats joined overwhelming numbers of Republicans who cited terrorism, moral values and the economy as the major reasons for supporting Mr. Bush over Mr. Kerry, according to surveys of voters. 
 The polls also showed that more than a majority of voters in the state, 56 percent, said they approved of the way the president was handling his job, and 58 percent said they felt the country was safer from terrorism than it was four years ago.
 It was the second time Mr. Bush carried the state, after defeating Al Gore by six percentage points in 2000.
 Democrats did not, however, abandon other Democratic candidates in large numbers. Both of the state's Democratic House members -- Representatives Alan B. Mollohan and Nick J. Rahall II -- were safely re-elected to Congress. The lone Republican, Representative Shelley Moore Capito, shook off a Democratic challenge from Erik Wells, a former television anchor, to keep her seat.
 Democratic loyalties also helped Joseph Manchin III, West Virginia's secretary of state, win the governor's race, succeeding Bob D. Wise, a Democrat who did not seek a second term. Mr. Manchin, who ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1996, won 63 percent of the vote in defeating Monty Warner, a Republican, who had 34 percent, and Jesse Johnson of the Mountain Party, who had 2 percent.
 Mr. Manchin was aided by name recognition -- an uncle had served as secretary of state and state treasurer -- and by an overwhelming advantage in money. In the final weeks of the campaign, he spent $3.3 million, compared with $880,000 by Mr. Warner. 

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 418,151 -- 56%
Kerry: 321,641 -- 43%
Nader: 3,951 -- 1%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting

CORRECTION-DATE: November 5, 2004

 CORRECTION:
A chart in the elections section yesterday showing New York State returns for president and United States senator gave an outdated party affiliation for Ralph Nader. He was the candidate of both the Independence Party and the Peace and Justice Party; the Green Party was his affiliation in 2000.

PUB-DATE: November 4, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- MIDWEST; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 3589 words

HEADLINE: Some important victories for Kerry, but a death blow in Ohio.

BYLINE: Contributing to this report were Elissa Gootman, Patrick Healy, Michael Janofsky, Michael Luo, Jennifer Medina, Robert Pear, Richard Prez-Pea, Marc Santora, Stephanie Strom and Daniel J. Wakin.

 BODY:

ILLINOIS -- KERRY
 Barack Obama, a rising star in the Democratic Party with a compelling personal story, won election to the Senate in a sweeping victory, defeating the Republican, Alan Keyes, by the biggest margin ever in an Illinois Senate race, far greater than Senator Kerry's margin over President Bush.
 Mr. Obama, 43, became the only African-American elected to the Senate this year and the third since Reconstruction. He won with 70 percent of the vote. 
 ''We will not be measured by the margin of our victory, but we will be measured by whether we are able to deliver concrete improvements to the lives of so many people all across this state,'' Mr. Obama said. He fills the seat previously held by Peter G. Fitzgerald, a Republican who is retiring.
 Mr. Obama spoke well after the election results were clear, but before Mr. Keyes was willing to give up. Mr. Keyes, 54, entered the race late, after another Republican, Jack Ryan, dropped out following allegations in divorce papers involving sex clubs. 
 On Tuesday night, Mr. Keyes did not formally concede even after Mr. Obama spoke. Instead, waving his arms for emphasis, he repeated his campaign themes opposing gay marriage and denouncing support for abortion as he quoted from a biblical passage about people ''wandering off into myths.''
 Still, it was Mr. Obama's night. The young Democrat came to national attention after his keynote address at the Boston nominating convention, where he related his experience as the son of a white mother from Kansas and a black father from Kenya. He used his personal experience to build a campaign theme of bridging divides.
 Illinois Democrats also had success in House races, picking up two seats.

PRESIDENT
98% reporting
Kerry: 2,753,525 -- 55%
Bush: 2,225,320 -- 44%

SENATE
98% reporting
Obama: 3,425,074 -- 70%
Keyes: 1,319,920 -- 27%

INDIANA -- BUSH
 One of the best examples of the Bush administration's efforts to build a legacy at the state as well as the federal level is Indiana's incoming governor, Mitch Daniels. 
 Mr. Daniels left his post as director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Bush White House in 2003 to return to his adopted home state and spend the next year and a half cruising Indiana in a recreational vehicle and introducing himself in person to the people he hoped would become his supporters.
 His stint as a vagabond paid off handsomely on Tuesday, when he easily captured the Statehouse from Gov. Joseph E. Kernan, the Democrat who took the job last year when Frank O'Bannon died suddenly, and was ambivalent about trying to retain it.
 Mr. Daniels has promised to address the state's flagging economy and restore jobs.
 Although Senator Evan Bayh, a Democrat, easily held on to his seat, power in the state over all shifted toward the Republicans. Mr. Daniels will be the first Republican to hold the state's top job in 16 years, and the party also regained control of the State House of Representatives for the first time since 1996.
 Representative John Hostettler, a Republican who gained notoriety when he tried to board a plane with a loaded gun, had an easier time retaining his job than many had expected, but Representative Julia Carson, a Democrat, who will also be returning to Washington, had a much closer race than was forecast. 
 But Indiana's Congressional delegation did lose one Democrat, Baron P. Hill, a three-term incumbent. In a fight too close to call until midday yesterday, Mr. Hill lost to Mark Sodrel, a Republican who is a trucking executive. Last spring, when Vice President Dick Cheney appeared at a fund-raiser for a Republican challenger, Mr. Hill remarked: ''I don't need people from Washington, D.C., coming out here and propping me up. I'll do it on my own.''
 He may be having second thoughts about that now.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 1,470,396 -- 60%
Kerry: 958,429 -- 39%

SENATE
100% reporting
Bayh: 1,485,090 -- 62%
Scott: 897,760 -- 37%

GOVERNOR
100% reporting
Daniels: 1,294,870 -- 53%
Kernan: 1,102,980 -- 45%

IOWA
 President Bush held on to a narrow lead in Iowa, and if he ultimately won, he would be the first Republican in 20 years to carry the state, which he lost by less than half a percentage point in 2000.
 State officials said they would need several days to count thousands of provisional ballots and absentee ballots. The secretary of state, Chet Culver, said the presidential race in Iowa was too close to call.
 Civic participation normally runs high in Iowa, but Mr. Culver said the turnout, about 75 percent of registered voters, set a record.
 Survey of voters leaving the polls showed that voters under 30 and those 60 or over tended to support Senator Kerry, while Mr. Bush had an edge among those in between.
 Gov. Tom Vilsack campaigned for Mr. Kerry. Opinion polls in the final days of the campaign indicated that Mr. Kerry might win the state, where his presidential campaign first gained momentum in the party caucuses early this year. 
 But by working hard in Republican areas of western Iowa, the Bush campaign offset the advantage that Mr. Kerry had in the eastern part of the state.
 Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, won a fifth term, with 70 percent of the vote. He got 68 percent in 1998 and nearly 70 percent in 1992. He has been an indispensable ally of the White House in enacting the tax cuts at the heart of President Bush's agenda. He was an architect of the law that added prescription drug coverage to Medicare. And he is a zealous protector of federal employees who expose waste and fraud in federal programs.
 Mr. Grassley defeated Arthur Small, a lawyer and former state legislator. Democrats said Mr. Grassley was too close to drug and insurance companies. But at scores of town meetings around the state, he defended the Medicare law as a way to deliver long-promised benefits to the elderly.
 The state's five House members, including Jim Nussle, the chairman of the Budget Committee, and three other Republicans, won re-election.
 Republicans had hoped that Representative Leonard L. Boswell, a relatively conservative Democrat, might be vulnerable. The Republican challenger, Stan Thompson, waged an aggressive campaign but won only 45 percent of the vote, and Mr. Boswell will return to Washington for a fifth term.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 745,742 -- 50%
Kerry: 732,492 -- 49%
Nader: 5,811 -- 0%

SENATE
100% reporting
Grassley: 1,025,501 -- 70%
Small: 403,399 -- 28%

KANSAS -- BUSH
 In this Republican stronghold, the state's six electoral votes were never seriously in doubt, with President Bush winning easily. 
 Similarly, in the Senate race, the Republican incumbent, Sam Brownback, won in a landslide, defeating Lee Jones, a railroad engineer. Mr. Jones became the Democratic nominee only after the winner in the primary, Robert Conroy, withdrew.
 Mr. Conroy, who said he had put his name on the ballot only to ensure that Mr. Brownback did not run unopposed, failed to campaign and still managed to win the nomination over Mr. Jones. He then pulled out without much explanation.
 But national and state Republican leaders once again failed to unseat Dennis Moore, the lone Democrat in the state's Congressional delegation, who has now beaten Republican opponents four times. He defeated Kris Kobach -- a law professor at the University of Missouri-Kansas City and former Justice Department official whose pedigree includes Harvard, Oxford and Yale -- with his largest margin yet. 
 Republican and Democratic leaders poured hundreds of thousands of dollars into the race. Mr. Kobach leaned heavily on the evangelical Christian vote, portraying himself as a staunch protector of conservative social values, even campaigning at one point with the Rev. Jerry Falwell. Meanwhile Mr. Moore cast himself as a moderate, hoping to lure independent voters. 
 The state's three Republican incumbents in the House all won, including Jim Ryun, the former Olympic runner whose district covers most of the eastern part of the state. Mr. Ryun managed to stave off a furious challenge by Nancy Boyda, a political unknown who managed to keep the race close far longer than most national observers had predicted. The race got especially heated toward the end after Mr. Ryun ran a television advertisement that criticized his opponent's participation in antiwar rallies and featured images of Osama bin Laden. The unusually harsh tactic prompted some to wonder if the race was tightening. But Mr. Ryun won with 56 percent of the vote, compared with Ms. Boyda's 41 percent.

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 711,083 -- 62%
Kerry: 416,905 -- 36%
Nader: 8,955 -- 1%

SENATE
100% reporting
Brownback: 770,317 -- 69%
Jones: 305,226 -- 27%

MICHIGAN -- KERRY
 Senator Kerry beat President Bush by three percentage points in Michigan, a traditionally Democratic state that has suffered some of the worst job losses in the country.
 Michigan's governor and its two senators, all Democrats who were not up for re-election this year, focused on campaigning for Mr. Kerry. The senator defeated Mr. Bush by 40 percentage points in Wayne County, which includes Detroit.
 Mr. Kerry won strong support from unions and voters who said the economy was their biggest concern, surveys of voters showed. 
 Mr. Bush's supporters were most concerned with terrorism and moral values.
 Michigan was one of 11 states that approved a statewide ban on gay marriage. The ban, known as Proposal 2, won 59 percent of voter support. It was opposed by major newspapers and statewide politicians, but supporters ran a successful campaign in Roman Catholic and evangelical churches, raising $1.2 million. Opponents raised less than half of that.
 Voters also passed a proposal to limit new types of gambling, despite objections by Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm. The proposal, supported by 58 percent of voters, requires voter approval of new forms of legalized gambling, including slot machines and video lottery terminals.

PRESIDENT
97% reporting
Kerry: 2,393,251 -- 51%
Bush: 2,249,215 -- 48%
Nader: 23,171 -- 0%

MINNESOTA -- KERRY
 The power of incumbency in the House of Representatives was clear in the land of 10,000 lakes, where all eight officeholders won re-election. There was only one race that presented even a mild challenge to an incumbent. 
 Representative Mark Kennedy, a Republican, had to struggle to keep his seat. Patty Wetterling, the Democratic challenger, made a surge late in the race, but Mr. Kennedy was able to hold on. This means Minnesota will continue to have four Republicans and four Democrats in the House. 
 With no Senate races and no contest for governor, attention in this swing state focused mainly on which way it would break for president. While Bill Clinton won the state handily in 1996, beating Bob Dole by 16 percentage points, Al Gore barely won the state four years ago with a 2 percent margin. As in other parts of the country, the turnout was high, and the lines at polling stations were often long. Around midnight, it became clear that Senator Kerry would take the state and its 10 electoral votes by roughly the same margin as Mr. Gore.

PRESIDENT
98% reporting
Kerry: 1,411,010 -- 51%
Bush: 1,312,724 -- 48%
Nader: 18,109 -- 1%

MISSOURI -- BUSH
 Secretary of State Matt Blunt, a member of a three-generation political family, defeated State Auditor Claire McCaskill to bring the governor's office under Republican control. 
 There had been speculation that Mr. Blunt, 33, the son of Representative Roy Blunt, the House majority whip, would benefit from a strong showing by President Bush, and that appeared to be the case.
 Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that a slight majority approved of Mr. Bush's job performance and that those people in turn voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Blunt. Mr. Bush carried the state by seven percentage points.
 Mr. Blunt's conservative stands on social issues also helped him, the surveys said.
 In a nasty campaign that featured attack ads from both sides, Ms. McCaskill, 51, tried to highlight her long resume, which included stints in the State Legislature and as a county prosecutor. She wrested the Democratic nomination away from the incumbent, Bob Holden, in a bitter primary.
 Senator Christopher S. Bond, a Republican and a three-term incumbent, defeated State Treasurer Nancy Farmer, the Democratic challenger. 
 Meanwhile, Mr. Blunt's father won his Congressional race easily.
 The departures of Representatives Richard A. Gephardt and Karen McCarthy, both Democrats, left two open Congressional seats, but Democrats won both. 
 A former mayor of Kansas City, Emanuel Cleaver, beat Jeanne Patterson, a political newcomer, to fill Ms. McCarthy's seat. 
 Russ Carnahan, the son of former Senator Jean Carnahan and former Gov. Mel Carnahan, won the race for Mr. Gephardt's seat, defeating Bill Federer.

PRESIDENT

Bush: 1,452,715 -- 53%
Kerry: 1,253,879 -- 46%

Bond: 1,514,793 -- 56%
Farmer: 1,153,422 -- 43%

GOVERNOR

Blunt: 1,380,200 -- 51%
McCaskill: 1,296,362 -- 48%

NEBRASKA -- BUSH
 The Republican Party retained its hold on this heartland state, handing President Bush an even bigger victory than it did in 2000. 
 Jeff Fortenberry, 43, a Republican and publishing executive whose only experience in public life was a term on the Lincoln City Council, easily defeated Matt Connealy, the Democratic contender, to take the House seat vacated by Doug Bereuter, a Republican. Mr. Fortenberry, who ran what he called a campaign for ''strong families,'' gained strength in the final days of the campaign when Gov. Mike Johanns began stumping for him.
 Nebraskans also firmly refused to sanction gambling, despite a strong push by proponents who were backed by Nevada gambling companies. A constitutional amendment to allow two casinos near Omaha was rejected, as were two of three initiatives would have opened the state to gambling.
 ''It's a great story of citizens uniting to fight the giant and winning,'' said Pat Loontjer, executive director of Gambling With the Good Life, an antigambling grassroots movement supported by churches, state political figures and Warren E. Buffett, the investor.

PRESIDENT
90% reporting
Bush: 445,839 -- 67%
Kerry: 213,837 -- 32%
Nader: 4,776 -- 1%

NORTH DAKOTA -- BUSH
 By a margin of 46 percent, North Dakotans overwhelmingly approved a constitutional amendment to define marriage. The amendment establishes marriage as a union between a man and a woman and says that ''no other domestic union, however denominated, may be recognized as marriage or given the same or substantially equivalent legal effect.''
 Support for the amendment, however, did not appear to translate into support for conservative candidates, as some had expected. ''Our Democratic member of the House of Representatives won by the largest margin he ever had, and our Democratic senator also won by a huge margin,'' said Mary Kweit, a political science professor at the University of North Dakota. 
 North Dakota, with its predominantly elderly and rural population, is considered a conservative state, yet all its delegates to Congress are Democrats. Senator Byron L. Dorgan had a 36 percent margin over his Republican challenger, Mike Liffrig, a lawyer. Representative Earl Pomeroy, a Democrat, relished a 20 percent margin over his opponent, Duane Sand.
 Yet Gov. John Hoeven, a Republican, won another term. He campaigned on concern about the state's weak economy and job losses and won support from groups that have traditionally backed Democrats, like the state teachers' union, whose members have received two raises during his tenure in the Statehouse.
 Similarly, President Bush easily defeated Senator Kerry here to win the state's three electoral votes. 
 ''That is the eternal mystery of North Dakota politics,'' Professor Kweit said of the public's voting allegiances. ''The explanation I always give is that this is a very small state, just 638,000 people, and the congressional delegation, all of whom are Democrats, do a wonderful job of maintaining contact with people back here. People don't think of a vote for Byron being a vote for a Democrat, they think about voting for Byron.''

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 194,668 -- 63%
Kerry: 110,052 -- 36%
Nader: 3,712 -- 1%

SENATE
99% reporting
Dorgan: 210,209 -- 68%
Liffrig: 97,554 -- 32%

GOVERNOR

Hoeven: 218,682 -- 71%
Satrom: 84,182 -- 27%

OHIO -- BUSH
 All eyes ended up looking at Ohio and its 100,000-plus vote lead for President Bush in the hours after the election. Its 20 electoral votes could have given Senator Kerry victory, but the point became moot when he conceded.
 Ohio's sagging economy and job losses proved a boost for Mr. Kerry, voter surveys showed. The worse Ohioans thought of both, the more they were likely to vote for him. He also scored higher than the president in union households. President Bush scored well among older, wealthier and more religious voters.
 George V. Voinovich, a former governor and mayor of Cleveland, continued his forceful presence in Ohio politics, handily winning a second term as senator against Eric Fingerhut, a Democratic state senator. 
 Ohio was one of 11 states that had a ballot measure to bar same-sex marriages, and all passed with strong margins. Ohio's measure was for a state constitutional amendment to define marriage as between a man and a woman, but more drastically, for a ban on any status that ''intends to approximate'' a marriage, meaning partnership benefits like health insurance could be affected. The measure carried by a 62 percent to 38 percent margin. 
 It won despite opposition from Senator Voinovich, his fellow Republican Senator Mike DeWine, figures in business and the clergy, the president of Ohio State University and the state attorney general. Opponents argued the amendment would prevent private firms or public universities from granting benefits to unmarried couples, hurting Ohio's competitiveness. Ohio already has a law banning gay marriage, but supporters said the measure would prevent a judge from overturning it. 

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 2,796,147 -- 51%
Kerry: 2,659,664 -- 49%

SENATE
100% reporting
Voinovich: 3,378,356 -- 64%
Fingerhut: 1,906,648 -- 36%

SOUTH DAKOTA -- BUSH
 In a race as important for its symbolism as for its impact, John Thune, a Republican, ousted the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle, a veteran of South Dakota politics for nearly 30 years. 
 Mr. Thune, who served three terms in the House, criticized Mr. Daschle in the campaign, saying he was more in tune with the politics of Capitol Hill than the concerns of South Dakota residents. The race remained tight until early yesterday, locked in a dead heat for much of Tuesday night. 
 The loss makes Mr. Daschle the first Senate party leader in more than five decades to be voted out of office. The race had been closely watched by both parties, with White House officials calling the senator an obstructionist for opposing the president on the war in Iraq, tax cuts and judicial nominees. Senator Daschle had fought hard, raising $16 million during the campaign as of mid-October, which he spent largely on television advertisements. Mr. Thune had raised $10 million by the same time.
 Several outside groups spent additional large sums of money to pay for advertisements opposing Senator Daschle.
 After being elected to the House in 1978, Mr. Daschle captured a Senate seat in 1986 and won each of his previous three bids for re-election with relative ease. 
 In 2002, Mr. Thune ran against Senator Tim Johnson and lost by fewer than 550 votes. Just as he did in that race, Mr. Thune said this year that he would be able to work well with Republicans in the Senate and with President Bush. 
 This time, Mr. Thune rode the strong wave of support for Mr. Bush, who won with the same 22 percent margin as he did in 2000. Several political analysts had said that the Senate race would probably be determined by the presidential vote. Senator Kerry received 38 percent of the vote, and Ralph Nader received 1 percent. 

PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush: 232,545 -- 60%
Kerry: 149,225 -- 38%
Nader: 4,317 -- 1%

SENATE
100% reporting
Thune: 197,814 -- 51%
Daschle: 193,279 -- 49%

WISCONSIN -- KERRY
 In Wisconsin, where Al Gore just barely defeated George W. Bush in 2000, Senator Kerry had a slight edge over President Bush this time. After weeks of fierce campaigning by both sides that culminated in rival rallies in Milwaukee on Monday, Mr. Kerry captured 50 percent of the vote to Mr. Bush's 49 percent.
 Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat, fought back a stiff challenge from Tim Michels, a Republican, winning 55 percent of the vote to earn a third term.
 Mr. Feingold, perhaps best known for championing campaign finance, and Mr. Michels, a wealthy construction company executive and former Army Ranger, clashed over a host of issues, like health care, taxes, the war in Iraq and the Patriot Act. 
 Mr. Feingold was the lone senator to vote against the act, saying he feared that it would infringe on civil liberties. Mr. Michels criticized Mr. Feingold for being too liberal, ran campaign commercials with images of the World Trade Center and voiced support for the Iraq war. 
 Mr. Feingold, in turn, portrayed Mr. Michels as a political novice, particularly after he acknowledged he had not read the Patriot Act in full. 
 The state's incumbent representatives, four Republicans and three Democrats, were re-elected, with Gwen Moore, a Democrat, winning the one open seat.

PUB-DATE: November 4, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section P; Column 1; National Desk; THE 2004 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE -- South; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 3503 words

HEADLINE: Strong performances by President Bush and Republican senators.

BYLINE: Contributing to this report were Elissa Gootman, Patrick Healy, Michael Janofsky, Michael Luo, Jennifer Medina, Robert Pear, Richard Prez-Pea, Marc Santora, Stephanie Strom and Daniel J. Wakin.

 BODY:

ALABAMA -- BUSH
 Alabama produced neither surprise nor drama on election night as the state showed itself as the Republican presidential stronghold it has been for the last three decades.
 President Bush built his 26-point victory on the strength of support from every age demographic and from all economic groups except the very poorest, according to voter surveys. 
 Only voters earning under $15,000 favored Senator Kerry.
 In winning a fourth term, Senator Richard C. Shelby finished even stronger than Mr. Bush, with a 36-point victory over Wayne Sowell, a Democrat who was the first black Senate candidate ever nominated by a major party in Alabama. Black voters were the only demographic group that gave him more votes than Mr. Shelby.
 The House races played out as pre-election polls predicted. All six incumbents who faced opposition -- four Republicans and two Democrats -- won easily. 
 Representative Spencer Bachus, a conservative Republican who represents majors parts of the Birmingham metropolitan area, had no Democratic opponent and thus won a seventh term.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 1,171,067 -- 63%
Kerry: 690,123 -- 37%
Nader: 6,658 -- 0%

SENATE
98% reporting
Shelby: 1,231,610 -- 68%
Sowell: 590,360 -- 32%

ARKANSAS -- BUSH
 Despite a last-minute appearance by former President Bill Clinton in his home state of Arkansas on Sunday, President Bush won the state by a greater margin than he did in 2000. Polls had shown the race tilting in Mr. Bush's favor over the summer but then tightening toward the end.
 In the Senate race, Blanche Lincoln, the Democratic incumbent, defeated State Senator Jim Holt, who made his opposition to gay marriage and his stance on other conservative social values the overriding theme of his campaign. 
 He tried to paint his opponent as ultraliberal, but Ms. Lincoln argued that she was a centrist, and she drew the endorsement of several conservative groups.
 She had served two terms in the House before quitting to raise children but then returned to politics in 1998 to claim the Senate seat vacated by Dale Bumpers. 
 With Democrats losing Senate races throughout the South on Tuesday, she and Senator Mark Pryor, also of Arkansas, are among the few Democratic senators left in the region.
 In the state's three contested House races, incumbents all won, including Vic Snyder, a Democrat, whose opponent, State Representative Marvin Parks, also tried to draw distinctions based on their stances on social issues. 
 John Boozman, a Republican, and Marion Berry, a Democrat, easily defeated their opponents. 
 Voters also passed a state ballot measure banning gay marriage.

PRESIDENT
97% reporting
Bush: 546,316 -- 54%
Kerry: 452,090 -- 45%
Nader: 5,892 -- 1%

SENATE
97% reporting
Lincoln: 555,199 -- 56%
Holt: 437,744 -- 44%

FLORIDA -- BUSH
 President Bush won a crucial victory in Florida, the site of an agonizing recount four years ago, and his former secretary of housing and urban development, Mel Martinez, won the Senate seat being vacated by Bob Graham, an influential Democrat.
 Mr. Bush won more than 75 percent of the vote in a handful of counties in north Florida and won support from swing voters in central Florida, while Senator Kerry's best showing came in southeast Florida, including Broward and Palm Beach Counties.
 The president carried several counties in central Florida, like Hernando and Pasco, that he lost to Al Gore in 2000.
 After a tight, hard-fought race that included personal attacks, the Democrats' Senate candidate, Betty Castor, conceded yesterday to Mr. Martinez, who will become the first Cuban American in the Senate. 
 Ms. Castor, a former president of the University of South Florida, said her race was so close that it reminded her of the last presidential election. ''I was conjuring up 2000,'' she said.
 Mr. Martinez will provide an additional vote for the Bush administration on many issues. He has supported the war in Iraq; opposes abortion and embryonic stem cell research; would limit noneconomic damages in medical malpractice suits; and would allow younger workers to set aside some of their Social Security taxes in private retirement accounts.
 Representative Katherine Harris, the former state official who was at the center of disputed election rulings in the 2000 presidential recount battle, won her bid for a second term. In the Florida Panhandle, Representative Allen Boyd, a conservative Democrat, won a fifth term.
 Voters approved an increase in the minimum wage and decided to give the public more information about doctors' mistakes and to take away the medical licenses of doctors who make repeated errors.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 3,836,217 -- 52%
Kerry: 3,459,299 -- 47%
Nader: 32,036 -- 0%

SENATE
99% reporting
Martinez: 3,551,629 -- 49%
Castor: 3,470,405 -- 48%

GEORGIA -- BUSH
 President Bush easily defeated Senator Kerry, as was expected; in the 10 previous presidential elections, Georgians backed the Democratic candidate only three times, including twice when Jimmy Carter, a Georgian, was the nominee. 
 In the race to succeed Senator Zell Miller, a Democrat who harshly criticized Mr. Kerry at the Republican National Convention and did not seek re-election, the Republican candidate, Representative Johnny Isakson, defeated Representative Denise L. Majette, a Democrat. 
 By vacating her House seat to run for the Senate, Ms. Majette angered some supporters of her successful bid two years ago to unseat Cynthia A. McKinney, the Democratic firebrand known for her incendiary remarks, including a suggestion that Mr. Bush might have known about the Sept. 11 attacks but did nothing to stop them. Ms. McKinney, who was more subdued this time around, won the seat back. 
 In a heavily contested Congressional race, John Barrow, a Democrat, unseated Representative Max Burns, a Republican, in a district drawn to favor Democratic candidates. Mr. Burns had criticized Mr. Barrow for declining to say how he would vote on a proposed state constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. 
 That measure passed, although opponents said they planned to challenge its legality. 
 In another contested House race, Representative Jim Marshall, a Democrat, held his seat against Calder Clay, a Republican he narrowly beat two years ago. 

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 1,787,218 -- 59%
Kerry: 1,239,804 -- 41%

SENATE
99% reporting
Isakson: 1,735,297 -- 58%
Majette: 1,170,343 -- 39%

KENTUCKY -- BUSH
 The race for Senator Jim Bunning's seat gave Republicans one of their few serious scares of election night. But with a heavy pro-Bush turnout, especially in rural western Kentucky, Mr. Bunning held off a late charge by State Senator Daniel Mongiardo, a Democrat.
 Mr. Bunning, a Baseball Hall of Fame pitcher, has a reputation for being irascible, and he won his seat six years ago by a slim margin. But as a conservative incumbent in a conservative state, facing a little-known and underfinanced opponent, he was a heavy favorite this year. For months, polls showed him with a double-digit lead.
 But the race turned raucous in the final weeks, and Dr. Mongiardo climbed in the polls. Mr. Bunning said his opponent resembled a son of Saddam Hussein, then apologized for the remark. He refused to attend a scheduled debate, instead taking part by satellite from Washington, where he read some remarks from a teleprompter.
 Mr. Bunning, 73, said that he was unaware of widely reported news from Iraq and that he had not read a newspaper in six weeks. He charged that a Mongiardo aide had physically assaulted his wife, which Democrats denied.
 Democrats seized on the senator's behavior, calling him out of touch and questioning his physical and mental health. Mr. Bunning then released medical records and saying that Dr. Mongiardo was inexperienced and had accomplished nothing in government.
 In one of the nation's most closely watched and one of the most expensive House races, Geoff Davis, a Republican, won a seat that was held by a Democrat, Ken Lucas, who retired. Mr. Davis, a businessman, defeated Nick Clooney, a former television news reporter and newspaper columnist and the father of the actor George Clooney, by a 11 percentage points.

LOUISIANA -- BUSH
 For the first time since Reconstruction, Louisiana has elected a Republican senator, Representative David Vitter. Mr. Vitter defeated three major Democratic rivals to win the seat left open by John B. Breaux, a moderate Democrat retiring this year.
 Mr. Vitter, the only Republican candidate, won 51 percent of the vote, defeating his nearest rival by 22 percentage points. Mr. Vitter had been expected to win a plurality, but he needed the majority to avoid a runoff election in December.
 Elliot Stonecipher, a Louisiana political consultant, said the campaign offered ''an alignment of everything the gods could offer'' to a Republican in the state. 
 Heavy rains along the Gulf Coast probably kept many voters at home, Mr. Stonecipher said. After the presidential campaigns shifted their energy and money away from Louisiana, interest in the statewide races dissipated. 
 And a barrage of negative advertisements from the Democrats seemed to backfire, further building Mr. Vitter's lead. Mr. Stonecipher said the three Democrats ''hit him with the kitchen sink'' with ads attacking Mr. Vitter for things like old traffic tickets.
 Two House races in Gulf Coast districts will be decided by runoff elections. 
 In the Third District, Billy Tauzin III, a Republican, finished first, with a 32 percent plurality. In the Seventh District, another Republican, Charles Boustany, won with a 39 percent plurality.

MISSISSIPPI -- BUSH

Mississippians overwhelmingly approved a ballot measure to ban gay marriage, easily surpassing Gov. Haley Barbour's hope that the initiative would get at least 80 percent of the vote. The constitutional amendment is expected to give more power to a state law that already prohibits such unions, but opponents say they still intend to fight the measure in court.
 Each of the four House incumbents was re-elected with a healthy margin. Republicans Roger Wicker and Charles W. Pickering Jr. each received about 80 percent of the vote, with no Democratic challengers. Representatives Bennie Thompson and Gene Taylor will remain the state's only Democrats in Congress. 
 President Bush sailed to win the state's six electoral votes. The last time the state chose the Democratic candidate was in 1976, when it went for Jimmy Carter.

97% reporting
Bush: 649,859 -- 59%
Kerry: 435,570 -- 40%
Nader: 2,965 -- 0%

NORTH CAROLINA -- BUSH
 Republicans called North Carolina their three-B state, for Bush, Burr and Ballantine, the party's candidates for president, senator and governor, respectively.
 They emerged from the election with two out of three. President Bush won by 13 percentage points, and Representative Richard M. Burr picked up the Senate seat left vacant by John Edwards, the Democratic nominee for vice president.
 But Gov. Michael F. Easley, a Democrat, fended off a challenge from the Republican, Patrick Ballantine, winning 55 percent to 43 percent.
 Party control of the state's House seats did not change hands.
 Mr. Bush was widely expected to carry North Carolina, but until recently, Democrats were confident they would win the state's Senate race.
 This summer, Mr. Burr was 10 points behind his Democratic rival, Erskine Bowles, President Bill Clinton's former chief of staff. After losing an earlier Senate bid to Elizabeth Dole in 2002, Mr. Bowles campaigned this year as a shirtsleeves moderate. He traveled on a bus and said he was not beholden to the interests of the Democratic Party.
 The race narrowed in the fall as Mr. Burr ran a fusillade of television advertisements negatively comparing Mr. Bowles to President Clinton. 
 Mr. Burr also won ground after Congress passed a $10 billion federal tobacco buyout favored by many farmers.
 The race, which cost $20 million, was one of the most expensive Senate contests in the country. Mr. Bowles pumped $2.6 million of his own money into the campaign in October. Yesterday, victorious Republicans jabbed at Mr. Bowles and Mr. Edwards, both multimillionaires, by saying that Mr. Burr's victory proved that the Senate seat was not reserved for the wealthy.

OKLAHOMA -- BUSH
 As the fierce race for an open Senate seat finished, the Republican, former Representative Tom Coburn, led in most polls, though not by much. But in the end, it was not close. The Bush tide buoyed Dr. Coburn; turnout in this solidly Republican state was up by 20 percent from 2000.
 A month ago, the contest looked like a dead heat, thanks in part to the iconoclasm of Dr. Coburn, a fiscal conservative who criticized both parties for budget deficits and pork barrel spending. Party leaders had backed more moderate Republicans to succeed Senator Don Nickles, who is retiring, but Dr. Coburn easily won the primary.
 Democrats charged that Dr. Coburn was out of the mainstream, noting that he opposed spending even for projects in Oklahoma. He replied that his views would make his voice an independent one in Washington.
 Dr. Coburn, a family physician, was hurt by allegations that he had sterilized an under-age patient against her will and committed Medicaid fraud in that case -- charges that he denied -- and for a time, his Democratic opponent, Brad Carson, pulled even or slightly ahead in most polls. But in the last month, Republican officials and antitax groups lavished resources on the race, calling Mr. Carson a liberal. He tried hard to distance himself from Senator Kerry, whom he halfheartedly endorsed, but conservatives often reminded voters of the connection.
 A defining moment came in a debate last week, when the candidates were asked what they would do when their own views clashed with those of most Oklahomans. Mr. Carson said he would defer to his constituents; Dr. Coburn said he would follow his conscience, regardless of public opinion.
 By a three-to-one margin, Oklahoma voters approved a ban on same-sex marriage, and by almost two-to-one, they voted to create a state lottery.

SOUTH CAROLINA -- BUSH
 Standing by his staunch conservative ideology proved successful for Jim DeMint, a three-term Republican congressman, in the South Carolina Senate race. Mr. DeMint defeated Inez Tenenbaum, a Democrat, 54 percent to 44 percent. His victory for the seat, held since 1966 by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat who is retiring, contributed to the Republicans' increased majority in the Senate. 
 Mr. DeMint was helped by President Bush, who carried the state with 58 percent of the vote. Ms. Tenenbaum had tried to distance herself from the national party, but seemed unable to shake accusations that she was too liberal for the conservative state. 
 Democrats had counted on a strong showing by young and black voters to help Ms. Tenenbaum, the state superintendent of education. She had fared better in polls in recent weeks after Mr. DeMint said that gays and single mothers should not be public school teachers. (He later softened his remarks.) 
 But voter surveys on Tuesday showed that Mr. DeMint had done surprisingly well among black voters, whose support Ms. Tenenbaum had counted on. 
 Mr. DeMint repeatedly said he would be able to work closely with other Republicans in the Senate, including his ally, Senator Lindsey Graham. The two will be the first pair of Republicans to hold the state's Senate seats since Reconstruction. Republicans now hold four of the state's six House seats.

TENNESSEE -- BUSH
 The night of uncertainty over the presidential race could have been dispelled by a quick look at Tennessee, which has not backed a losing presidential candidate since 1960, even to the detriment of its native son Al Gore in 2000. President Bush easily won its 11 electoral votes on Tuesday, defeating Senator Kerry with a 15-point margin.
 In other races, Lincoln Davis, a Democrat, kept his House seat, beating Janice Bowling in a replay of their race two years ago. The eight other incumbents, divided equally between both parties, also returned to office with wide margins of victory. There were no races for Senate seats or for governor.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 1,381,237 -- 57%
Kerry: 1,032,789 -- 42%
Nader: 8,832 -- 0%

TEXAS -- BUSH

The incendiary redistricting in Texas -- engineered by Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, and aimed at ensuring the Republican grip on the House of Representatives -- met with tremendous success except for one significant race.
 Representative Chet Edwards, a Democrat and a veteran of tough election battles, defeated his Republican challenger, State Representative Arlene Wohlgemuth, by a margin of 4 percent. He managed to win even though Fort Hood, where he had cultivated loyal constituents with his attention to military and veterans' affairs, was cut out of his new district by the DeLay plan.
 The district includes Crawford, the tiny town where President Bush has his ranch, but Mr. Edwards's victory came as little surprise to W. Leon Smith, editor of The Lone Star Iconoclast and The Clifton Record, which endorsed Senator Kerry. ''He's very well-liked and trusted,'' Mr. Smith said of Mr. Edwards. ''He's voted with Bush on a lot of initiatives over the last four years, and he has a rural mind-set, which meets the criteria for this area. He's a family man, and he's really worked hard for this district.''
 Ms. Wohlgemuth ran a take-no-prisoners campaign in a district that Mr. Smith described as ''made-to-order for her'' but could not defeat the seven-term incumbent.
 In an interview yesterday with the nationally syndicated talk-show radio host Mike Gallagher, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas chided his party for bungling the race. ''When you look at of the contested races out there, the Democrats only won one and the fact of the matter is, anecdotal evidence tells us the only reason they won that one is because of a poorly run campaign by the Republicans,'' Governor Perry said.
 Two other longtime Democratic incumbents, Charles W. Stenholm and Martin Frost, did not fare as well, losing their seats to Republican incumbents Randy Neugebauer and Pete Sessions, respectively. 
 Louis Gohmert, a Republican and former judge, won the seat held by Max Sandlin, a Democrat, and Ted Poe, another former judge, ousted Nick Lampson, another Democratic incumbent.
 The defeat of those four Democrats shifted control of the Texas House delegation to the Republicans, who now hold 20 of the state's 32 seats. In 2003, the Democrats held 17 of them.
 Mr. DeLay, who twice was recently faulted by the House Ethics Committee, had no problem retaining his seat.

PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush: 4,495,797 -- 61%
Kerry: 2,816,501 -- 38%

VIRGINIA -- BUSH
 President Bush carried the state once again, making it 40 years and counting since Virginia went Democratic in a presidential election. Aides to Senator Kerry had hoped the streak would end this year, with the state's population shifting toward the north, which has a less of a conservative emphasis. 
 The Democrats invested heavily in television advertisements over the summer and, after seeming to back away in September, sent $50,000 more to the state in the campaign's final days. They had been counting on support from voters in Northern Virginia and along the coast, where they hoped Mr. Kerry's status as a decorated veteran would help with the region's concentration of military bases. But Mr. Bush's strength in rural parts of the state, as well as in the conservative suburbs, trumped any inroads Mr. Kerry made. 
 Democrats were disappointed as well in the race for a seat vacated by Representative Edward L. Schrock, a Republican who suddenly withdrew after allegations were published on a Web site that he had solicited gay sex through a telephone service. Despite having only 60 days to put together a campaign, Thelma Drake, a Norfolk real estate agent and Republican member of the State House of Delegates, defeated David B. Ashe, a lawyer and Marine veteran, in a heavily conservative district. Incumbents won in the 10 other House races. 
 In Richmond, L. Douglas Wilder, who 15 years ago became the country's first black elected governor, was elected mayor of his hometown, capping a political comeback.

Kerry: 1,408,405 -- 46%
