PUB-DATE: November 7, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 7; Column 2; Book Review Desk; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: His Horses Used to Fly

BYLINE: By D. T. Max

 BODY:

THE PACIFIC
And Other Stories.
By Mark Helprin.
366 pp. The Penguin Press. $25.95.
 MARK HELPRIN is both a fiction writer and a political writer. As the latter, he seems to think America is in bad shape. Writing in conservative outlets like The Wall Street Journal's op-ed page, he denounces Americans as pacifist and lacking in ''rigorous thought.'' No bigger put-down appears in his writing than the word ''French.'' His solution is to revive the military virtues -- honor, pride and the disciplined exercise of will. Over the years, he has generally avoided infusing this martial, almost militaristic, worldview into his many novels and stories. Fiction, his work has usually asserted, is about life. It gains power from invention, relativism and even sloppiness. In the 1980 story ''Ellis Island,'' a quick-change artist proves that ''truth is not anchored to the ground by driven piles. It can float and take to the air; it is light and lovely and delicate. It is feminine as well as masculine.'' In the sprawling 1983 novel ''Winter's Tale,'' a horse flies and a thief triumphs.
 In his new collection of 16 short stories, ''The Pacific,'' it is the op-ed Helprin who is in control. These are mostly didactic tales, rigid with anxiety. All but two of them are about men, and though they range from the late 19th century to the present, New York to Latin America to Italy to Israel, he is usually the same man. He is dignified, private and judgmental. If he was not a soldier, he wishes he had been. The people around him don't appreciate his strengths. They care about things, things and more things: ''cars and pools and appliances and Picassos.'' Not the Helprin protagonist. ''What I want I cannot have,'' says the elderly lawyer in the very short story ''Reconstruction,'' ''I cannot ride in my father's arms. I cannot know any of the great store of his memories that he did not tell me.'' The other main characters in ''The Pacific'' are formed -- really deformed -- by similar losses: a father or wife or sister who died too soon, a loss no number of consumer goods can plug.
 We don't find out how the protagonist of ''Reconstruction'' would fill the hole at the center of his soul. But Helprin gives us an answer in other stories. By wanting and renouncing we grow pure, and purity gives us the moral strength and rigor to face our mortality. This is the soldier's answer. Thus in the story ''Sail Shining in White,'' an accomplished sailor awaits a hurricane that is going to hit Florida and destroy his home. The landlubbers, the condo owners, the police, are terrified as the huge storm approaches. Because he alone lives a life free of vanity or possessions, he can save himself. Perhaps for that reason, he chooses not to. More likely, it is because he is haunted by the loss of his wife, Sabrina. In any event, he decides to commit suicide by sailing into the hurricane. At story's end, we leave him doing 30 knots, the sails of his Halifax 40 perfectly trimmed, the ''tritium hands'' of his watch glowing, entering ''a terrible darkness tinged with light.'' 
 Where does Helprin's pessimism come from? It is almost Gallic in its intensity. In ''A Brilliant Idea and His Own,'' an unnamed British officer parachutes into enemy-occupied Italy to help signal allied warships the location of the German artillery. His move appears suicidal but he has something to die for. By contrast, Helprin's other main characters often turn their backs on life to no purpose. Why is all their emotional energy going into the question of mortality, a problem they cannot solve?
 It's hard to say. The characters in these stories live by the credo that the examined life is not worth living. And Helprin wrote these stories over more than 20 years. But in the recent stories he seems to be responding to a change in our environment, and that change is clearly Sept. 11. Before that date, the death wish in Helprin's fiction was held off by the fecundity of his imagination. At times, his characters pledged themselves to purity and honor, but their author was busy playing the life-affirming game of fiction. The result was often quite good: ''Ellis Island'' is a marvelous story; ''A Winter's Tale'' is a prodigious, imaginative vibration of a novel.
 Now after thousands died in a few moments, such play may seem inappropriate to Helprin. ''Monday,'' one of the longer stories in the collection, best illustrates this stance. Fitch, a successful New York contractor, is a man more or less in and of the world. Then he gets a call from a woman named Lilly. He had worked for her and her husband before. Mysteriously, there is no husband now, and Fitch suspects divorce. It emerges that Lilly's husband died in the south tower. Fitch has his own Sept. 11 memory: he was working on Joralemon Street in Brooklyn Heights when the attacks came. He watched the towers fall. Now he embarks on a scheme: he will rehab Lilly's new duplex without charge. His men volunteer to help him in this economic suicide. ''That is still very much in the heart of my country,'' says Gustavo, one of his foremen. In just two months, they build Lilly a perfect space, going beyond her specs. ''She had certainly not ordered a marble floor, nor the beautiful millwork, nor the pinpoint recessed lighting, nor the coco mat flush with the floor,'' Helprin writes. At the end of the tale, Lilly calls Fitch to thank him -- a hint of a future romance is in the air -- but he chivalrously says nothing, ''for he knew that she needed time to regain her composure.'' 
 ''Monday'' is an unappealing story for the same reason ''Sail Shining in White'' and most of the others here are. For one thing, there is the almost Petrarchan condescension toward women: What if Lilly hates coco mats? What does Fitch know about her grieving? And isn't it Fitch, the impacted and angry male, who needs time to regain his composure? The tone of the stories is third person portentous. When Fitch and his team work, ''everything ran at a wheeled pace, and what had to be done was done with energy and rapidity.'' The storm in ''Sail Shining in White'' is ''the kind of storm that alters the scales by which such things are measured.'' Sabrina's husband in that story remembers the way her ''grace and beauty had rolled across the water to him like the flower-scented air that cascades over a beach in the morning.'' 
 Many of these characters -- whether actors, soldiers, impresarios or contractors -- sound the same, as if they were standing on a hill with a pennon defying augury. Perhaps we should expect that from a writer trying to teach us right behavior. As a speechwriter for Bob Dole in 1996, Helprin put in the plain-growling senator's mouth unlikely wishes like ''let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth.'' This kind of talk works well at political conventions, but it makes for dull stories.
 Ultimately these verbal flaws reflect a moral one. Helprin's despairing men are there to make a point about America and in doing so they (and he) miss its power. America is unfocused. Its S.U.V.'s and power yachts -- Helprin calls the latter ''hubris in fiberglass'' -- drown out its grief. But this monstrous noise also constitutes our strength: we will defeat whatever threatens us, because we are always moving, always shouting: it is our commercial insatiability that will win in the end, not our martial discipline or our purity. This is not the sort of declaration that makes for good op-eds, the sort in which Helprin calls us ''senescent Ottomans.'' This truth is more like the truth of fiction, hovering above us, not so lovely and delicate as that truth, but nearly as ineffable. In ''The Pacific: And Other Stories,'' Helprin tries to grab it out of the air and drive it into the piles. Unfortunately, he succeeds.

LENGTH: 1382 words

HEADLINE: Clueless in New Jersey, Or Refreshingly Out of Touch?

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
POLITICAL candidates in New Jersey, and especially Republicans, like to accuse each other of being ''out of step'' with voters, or ''out of the mainstream,'' and therefore unfit for public office. But if the exit polls from last Tuesday's election are any measure, all of New Jersey is out of step with America. Even the Republicans are. 
 The nation's talking heads -- except maybe for a few who were out of step -- seized upon the finding that ''moral values'' came in ahead of Iraq, terrorism, the economy and everything else when voters were asked to name their main concern. In the poll that the major networks commissioned, 22 percent said moral values was their most important issue. 
 ''Moral values'' were not defined, although it is probably safe to say that these voters were not thinking about Plato. Everyone seems to know, in the context of a poll in the election campaign of 2004, what moral values are. 
 And New Jersey apparently is not too worried about them. Here, just 13 percent of respondents said they were voting primarily on moral values. (Terrorism came in first.) Even of all the blue states, only the voters of New York, at 12 percent, came in below us. 
 So what is wrong with New Jersey? Has this election shown the state's place on the fringes of society? 
 Steven Goldstein says it has. Mr. Goldstein, the gay-rights advocate who helped lead the domestic partnership bill through the New Jersey Legislature last winter, was taking stock the day after voters in 11 states overwhelmingly approved ballot measures to ban gay marriage, 8 of them extending to other forms of legal recognition for same-sex partnerships.
 First, Mr. Goldstein said, that was troubling. ''It's unbelievable,'' he said, ''the fact that I share my home with a partner is more threatening to people in America than Osama bin Laden.''
 But New Jersey, he said, is ''an oasis of justice in a vast cesspool of prejudice.''
 ''Nobody in their right mind has ever even suggested a referendum on gay marriage,'' he said. ''Even the Republicans who are culturally conservative in New Jersey, the few who are, have never used gay rights as a wedge issue.'' 
 And while they were not using terms like ''oasis of justice,'' Republicans in Trenton were friendly enough to the domestic partnership bill, which extended some rights and benefits to same-sex couples. The measure's opponents generally kept their thoughts to themselves. The Senate Republican leader, John O. Bennett, made an appeal for the measure on the floor. State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the Republican state chairman, was ''a joy to work with,'' Mr. Goldstein said, even if he did abstain in the floor vote. 
 Senator Kyrillos was cheerleading for his party last Wednesday, happily noting that President Bush lost the state by only 6 percentage points, as against 16 points in 2000, but he had nothing to say about God or gays or abortion. 
 Looking to the governor's race next year, the Republicans are pushing their own idea of moral values, which is refraining from graft.
 As for social issues, when asked why New Jersey bothers to have two political parties, Mr. Kyrillos replied, diplomatically: ''Parties are branded, and national issues and personalities play into it. But I think next year's race, if done smartly, is going to be fought on New Jersey territory, with New Jersey issues and concerns.'' 
 The new Senate Republican leader, Leonard Lance -- more of a cloth-coat Republican than a clear-the-brush Republican -- is generally un-Bush-like on matters of governance as well as social issues. In fact, he calls himself ''the biggest environmentalist in the Legislature'' and has staked out his place over the years as its biggest enemy of deficit spending.
 ''But I also think we respect what the pollsters describe as moral values,'' Senator Lance said, adding, ''not on a woman's right to choose, perhaps, but there are other issues.''
 Asked to elaborate, he paused and then offered, ''The president has set a higher tone in the White House than his predecessor.''
 The New Jersey Republican Party does have a right wing, exemplified by Bret D. Schundler, who plans to run again for governor next year, and whose anti-abortion views, fellow Republicans say, make him a sure loser. 
 But Mr. Schundler is surely, well, out of step with Republicans in Oklahoma, who on Tuesday elected a United States Senator who has urged the death penalty for doctors who perform abortions, or those in South Carolina, whose new senator says that single mothers should not be allowed to teach school.
 And in New Jersey it is hard to picture a Republican candidate -- Senator Lance, say? -- stepping out with rifle and camouflage and dangling a goose corpse for the cameras. 
 In the meantime, the Democrats are trying to protect bears, as many people would say moral values demand.
 You don't have to be a sociologist to know that people in Alabama and people in New Jersey have different perspectives, or that the urban-rural divide does not mean much in New Jersey, the most densely populated state in the nation. 
 The exit poll results were consistent, too, with New Jersey's high proportion of college graduates and Ph.D.'s (the state is No.1 in doctorates per 100,000 people), who across the nation voted disproportionately for Senator John Kerry.
 But New Jersey has a crucial distinction: ''Lack of born-agains,'' said Cliff Zukin of Rutgers, who has polled the state for years and on Tuesday night analyzed the national exit poll for NBC News.
 Mr. Zukin cited another recent survey in which about 26 percent of Americans identified themselves as ''white born-again Christians,'' while in New Jersey only 8 percent did. And it was the born-again Christian voters, Mr. Zukin said, who accounted for the strong showing of moral values in the national exit poll.
 ''In New Jersey we are just not ideological,'' he said. ''We are extremely tolerant. We are the 'whatever' state.''
 If the voters in New Jersey, like New York, showed limited concern about moral values, perhaps it is because they were so much more worried about terrorism, which has actually killed friends and relatives. Or perhaps they are tolerant, but no so tolerant of people they associate with the term ''moral values.''
 Whatever.

SECTION: Section 8; Column 1; Sports Desk; OUTDOORS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 805 words

HEADLINE: Some Special Spots In Shadow of Skyline

BYLINE: By Peter Kaminsky

 BODY:
Among Manhattan's many secret delights, none appear to be lesser known than the opportunities for an evening's fishing after knocking off work. 
 I find this surprising because striped bass, bluefish and albacore cavort from the shoals off Staten Island to the roiling currents beneath the Triborough Bridge in spring and in fall. 
 I first started fishing there 15 years ago with Joe Shastay, a Jersey City fireman and conservationist, and the first of the modern light-tackle captains on the harbor. 
 In those early days, before word got out about the annual local fish riot, one might see one or two anglers on the water. 
 With the explosion in popularity of saltwater fishing, Jamaica Bay and Montauk are now chockablock with sleek fishing craft, but New York Harbor is still very much virgin water. 
 Shastay still fishes exclusively in the Upper Harbor above the Narrows. This constrains, though it doesn't exhaust, flyfishing possibilities. 
 But fly or spin, there is something to be said for the extra jolt of fishing in late afternoon when the slanting sunlight dances around the glassy facades of the financial district. Shastay has grown a bit grayer since we first fished, but remains very much in shape (which he attributes in part to his job and in part to his passion, which is bow hunting for white tail). 
 Last week I took him up on his offer to check out the action. On a cloudy but pleasant day, I hopped on his Steigercraft moored outside the World Financial Center.
 Shastay's two customers arrived presently with a box of still warm pizza that we wolfed down as we glided out of the marina. One of them, Dan Welch, a bond trader, had served in the Navy on the U.S.S. Pargo, a Sturgeon class nuclear submarine. Welch's guest, Sean George, is also a bond trader.
 Within minutes, we found bass right up against the seawall on the north end of Governors Island. George's first cast brought a 20-inch striped bass to the boat. His fishing had been limited to freshwater, so this spunky saltwater fish in a moving tide proved to be quite a thrill. Welch quickly hooked two more fish and was equally pleased. Such nonstop action, so quickly, seemed too good to last, and it was. 
 If it is true, as Robert Frost said, that ''something there is that doesn't love a wall,'' I have found it equally true that something there is that will not allow a watchman to stand by while someone else is having a good time. 
 Sure enough, in short order, a uniformed fellow began pacing up and down the shore waving us away. At the same time, a Coast Guard boat, fitted with a no-nonsense machine gun, approached.
 ''Sorry, guys,'' the flak-vested Guardsman said, ''but you know how things are these days.'' We did not protest.
 We poked around the harbor a bit, heading up the East River toward one of my favorite spots, U Thant Island, just across from the United Nations. That rocky upthrust in the river bottom is quite dependable. Moreover, there is a pleasing symmetry to the annual assembly of migrating fish occurring at the same time that the General Assembly convenes ashore. 
 But, symmetry notwithstanding, the tide had died, and without moving water there was no sense fishing. Shastay spun the wheel, opened the throttle and headed south.
 ''Robbin's Reef?'' I guessed correctly. Shastay made straight for the little lighthouse that marks a rocky ledge about a quarter-mile from the Staten Island shore.
 When we arrived, the tide had just started to trickle in and, like an image taking shape in a slow dissolve, a patch of nervous water became an unmistakable rip as the incoming current washed over the bumps and hills beneath. In the early evening light, the churning rip looked like a black streak on the flanks of a striped bass. 
 Welch and George chucked their jigs over the rip and retrieved them rapidly. When the first half-dozen casts proved unproductive, I thought we might have to try another spot, but Shastay was certain. 
 Certainty in a guide, I have learned, isn't the same as a real world sure thing. Often it means, ''Well, I hope something happens.'' I reserved judgment until the Wall Street twosome had each hooked up a half-dozen times.
 We kept fishing, steadying ourselves every few minutes when a new set of waves lifted us as the Staten Island Ferry made its way back and forth. The Statue of Liberty looked particularly wonderful from that low angle. 
 I thought, as I often do when fishing there, of Kate Walker, who with her husband, John, tended the lighthouse at Robbin's Reef a hundred years ago. She even kept a little garden on a terrace of the tiny home they built at the base of the tower. I have always liked the economy and steadfastness of John's deathbed instructions to his wife.
 ''Keep the light, Kate,'' he is said to have said. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: FISHES (90%); SPORT FISHING (90%); MILITARY VESSELS (86%); ARMED FORCES (86%); MARINE VESSELS (78%); BONDS (68%); NAVAL VESSELS (68%); ARCHERY (65%); SPORT HUNTING (65%) Fish and Other Marine Life; Fishing, Sport; Bluefish; Albacore (Fish); Striped Bass

PERSON: Peter Kaminsky

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%) NEW YORK, USA (94%) UNITED STATES (94%) New York City

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: The Real National Pastime

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:

AMERICA'S GAME
The Epic Story of How Pro Football
Captured a Nation.
By Michael MacCambridge.
Illustrated. 552 pp. Random House. $27.95.
 WHEN Robert McNair paid $700 million to buy the Houston Texans expansion franchise in 1999, he confessed that he ''went higher than any reasonable person would go'' to get into the National Football League. Several months later, after winning an auction to acquire the Jets, Woody Johnson admitted that he ''flinched the whole way'' before agreeing to write a check for $635 million. What is so special about the N.F.L. that would make sensible businessmen worth billions fork over admittedly illogical sums for a sports team? The question is central to ''America's Game,'' an expansive and detailed history of the N.F.L. told in episodic style by Michael MacCambridge, whose admiration for the league and how it overtook baseball as the national pastime -- largely by making smarter business decisions at almost every conceivable juncture in its post-World War II history -- is evident on every page.
 MacCambridge deftly integrates well-chosen accounts of games with profiles of league visionaries and tales of television negotiations and internal meetings. As he did in ''The Franchise: A History of Sports Illustrated Magazine,'' MacCambridge combines prodigious interviewing and research with a savvy use of anecdotes, like those of a young midshipman, George Allen -- later the coach of the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins -- knocking on Albert Einstein's front door in Princeton hoping to play checkers and of the inquiry in 1939 by two owners into J. Edgar Hoover's interest in abandoning the pursuit of bank robbers to become commissioner. 
 ''America's Game'' is rarely about players, except for those who became symbols, like the stoic Baltimore Colts quarterback John Unitas, with his crew cut, hightop shoes and quirky delivery, or the rebellious Cleveland Browns running back Jim Brown, who understood the racial politics of his time and retired at the age of 29. Rather, MacCambridge focuses mainly on owners and coaches -- and not always the ones that an aficionado might expect. Founding fathers like George Halas, the Papa Bear, are background players; Dan Reeves, the former Los Angeles Rams owner, is one of MacCambridge's leading men. Reeves was a stockbroker who moved his money-losing Rams in 1946 from Cleveland to Los Angeles, built a glamorous, winning organization and forced the end of league segregation.
 The central figure is Alvin Ray Rozelle, better known as Pete, a lanky, affable public relations man who, soon after the end of World War II, was a student publicist at Compton Junior College, where the Rams held training camp. Fourteen years later, ensconced as the Rams general manager, he was the compromise choice of N.F.L. owners wearied by a 22-ballot deadlock over a replacement for Bert Bell, the commissioner who cried when he did not get his way with owners and died in late 1959 while watching a Philadelphia Eagles game. When Art Rooney, the Pittsburgh Steelers owner, told Frank McNamee, the Eagles owner, that Rozelle's name had been put into play, McNamee said: ''Great. Who the hell is Pete Rozelle?''
 Rozelle was the boy commissioner, 33 years old at his ascension, a chain smoker who was a subtle but hardball negotiator: he learned well and quickly how to make his owners money. His mastery of public relations endeared him to a sports media world that had never made the N.F.L. its priority, and his sophisticated marketing led him to realize that the gospel of pro football he preached would be spread by having its own studio, N.F.L. Films, and licensing division, N.F.L. Properties. He lobbied Congress for one antitrust exemption that let him negotiate a single national television package with CBS, which removed financial disparities between teams and became the wellspring of N.F.L. wealth, and a second one to permit the merger with the American Football League, which he solidified by promising the Louisiana congressman Hale Boggs a team in New Orleans.
 Rozelle was the very model of the modern sports commissioner. He developed the Super Bowl into a secular holiday, extended the league's egalitarian economics (some called it socialism; MacCambridge calls it ''equality of opportunity for all''), helped devise ''Monday Night Football'' and oversaw football's takeover of Sundays in living rooms and bars across the country.
 But all was not ideal. Rozelle greatly regretted his decision to play on the Sunday after John F. Kennedy's assassination -- which, MacCambridge says, can be explained by Rozelle's lack of understanding about the powerful role that television would play that weekend -- and retired in 1989 after a tiring decade pockmarked by player drug scandals, federal lawsuits challenging what Howard Cosell used to call the N.F.L.'s status as a ''duly adjudicated illegal monopoly'' and nearly ceaseless labor wars.
 The story does not end there, but the excitement does. MacCambridge's narrative flags and becomes disjointed in search of a continuing theme after Paul Tagliabue's election as commissioner. In the history of any other league, Tagliabue would be a seminal, singular figure. Over 15 years Tagliabue has overseen labor peace, inaugurated a free-agent system with a salary cap, negotiated $18 billion in television contracts that expire after the 2005 season and created the fledgling N.F.L. Network. But he has only made the league bigger. Rozelle, having come along at the right time, made it big and big-time.
 And if you follow the great-man theory espoused by MacCambridge, there are few great men now. Oh, there is a character like Jerry Jones, the Arkansas oilman who bought the Dallas Cowboys in 1989 and summarily fired one of the great men, Tom Landry (who ran his team for as long as Rozelle was commissioner). Jones's current coach, the nomadic and blustery Bill Parcells, plays a bit part. But there are no modern equivalents in ''America's Game'' of the flinty Paul Brown, for whom the Cleveland Browns were named (as was the stadium of the Cincinnati Bengals, a team owned by Brown's son), and whose ultraorganized approach to football was widely imitated.
 Similarly, there is no 21st-century peer in these pages of Lamar Hunt, the secretive son of a Texas oil tycoon who created the A.F.L. when his hopes of buying an N.F.L. team were spurned, then forged the merger with Rozelle. There is no one like Vince Lombardi, whose strategies redefined teamwork -- his power sweep rushing play exemplified a ''sense of enlightened cooperation for a larger cause,'' MacCambridge writes -- and whose exhortations are currently featured in an N.F.L. ad campaign, 34 years after his death.
 Ultimately, then, it is no surprise that billionaires make huge investments to become owners in the N.F.L. The league has the highest television ratings, the most television money, the best sponsorships, the most sophisticated marketing and public relations, the greatest interest from gamblers and fantasy-sports enthusiasts and the advantage of each team playing one game a week, which makes each one important. I'm not sure there are more reasons than these -- or if Robert McNair or Woody Johnson (or even Paul Tagliabue) thinks of pro football, as MacCambridge does, as ''the perfect symbol for the country's bustling, modernistic urgency, a splendid entertainment, a taxing and transforming profession, and a meaningful metaphor for the most American pursuit of all, those seemingly mismatched but inextricably bound ideas of competition and community.''


GRAPHIC: Drawings (Drawings by Stephen Savage)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: BOOK REVIEWS (90%); AMERICAN FOOTBALL (90%); SPORTS (90%); ATHLETES (89%); SPORTS & RECREATION (78%); SPORTS TEAM OWNERSHIP (74%); BASEBALL (73%); WORLD WAR II (72%); ROBBERY (63%); LITERATURE (60%); COMMUNITY COLLEGES (60%) Books and Literature; Reviews 

COMPANY: WASHINGTON FOOTBALL INC (54%)

ORGANIZATION: NATIONAL FOOTBALL LEAGUE (91%); HOUSTON TEXANS (84%); NEW YORK JETS (57%)

INDUSTRY: NAICS711211 SPORTS TEAMS & CLUBS (54%); SIC7941 PROFESSIONAL SPORTS CLUBS & PROMOTERS (54%)

PERSON: Richard Sandomir; Michael MacCambridge

GEOGRAPHIC: CLEVELAND, OH, USA (67%) TEXAS, USA (92%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); OHIO, USA (67%) UNITED STATES (94%)

Copyright 2004 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 11; Column 4; Real Estate Desk; STREETSCAPES; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1126 words

HEADLINE: On Waterfronts of the Present, Rail-Bridge Relics of the Past

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
AT two recently built waterfront parks, evocative industrial archaeology -- huge, rusting float bridges, once used for transferring freight cars to and from cross-river barges -- have been made integral parts of the design.
 At the six-year-old Gantry Plaza State Park, on the East River in Hunters Point, Queens, the float bridges are matte black paint and sharp orange lettering. But at the newer Riverside Park South, on the Hudson River below 72nd Street, the 69th Street float bridge is still a derelict amid a sweep of thigh-high grass and stainless-steel park furniture. A visit to both offers the opportunity to ponder our concepts of restoration -- and ruin. 
 The railroad marshaling yards along the Hudson River north of 59th Street show up on land maps of the 1870's, served by cross-Hudson bridges much farther up the river. But other rail operations just across the Hudson in New Jersey made it economical to barge entire rail cars over on car floats and bring them ashore using float bridges -- also called transfer bridges -- that hooked up to the car floats. 
 The early transfer bridges were simple, partly floating decks, hinged at the shoreline, with the water end floating on a pontoon system, rising and falling with the tide. Joining the pontoon end of the transfer bridge to the incoming car float took some time. 
 To speed the operation, several designers developed suspension systems that raised and lowered the transfer bridge from an overhead structure. In 1911, the New York Central Railroad built such a system, designed by James B. French, at the foot of West 69th Street. French patented his design, which uses two separate decks raised and lowered independently and a wide shed running across the top to protect the lifting machinery.
 French's design ''swept the field,'' says Thomas F. Flagg, an industrial archaeologist who has studied and written about transfer bridges for three decades. Mr. Flagg says that such an operation could unload 800 tons of cargo in 15 minutes. To a non-specialist, the rail-car transfer seems unwieldy, but it is faster than a modern container crane, Mr. Flagg says.
 In the mid-1920's, the Long Island Rail Road built several float bridges of the same design on the East River at Long Island City; they accommodated 100-ton cars and could rise and fall 18 feet.
 As American railroading -- and rail freight in the Port of New York -- declined drastically, these float bridges tumbled into disuse, and by the 1970's were wide open for graffiti, vandalism and urban adventure. In 1998, Gantry Plaza State Park opened at 48th and 49th Avenues, succeeding the Long Island Rail Road transfer point there. The landscape architects Thomas Balsley Associates incorporated float bridges into the design. (The park should be a must-see for most Manhattan tourists, in part for the dead-on Midtown Manhattan views.) 
 Anyone who grew up with the mid-20th century parks of the Robert Moses variety may weep on walking through Gantry; it's not that the Moses-era parks were so bad, it's that Balsley's inspired design shows how little extra it would have taken to make them so much better. There are four new finger piers reaching out into the East River. One, the most southerly -- it's called the fishing pier -- has a stainless steel fish-cleaning table in the shape of an amoeba. It also has a 100-foot-plus-long wooden slat bench, a ''wave bench'' that rises and falls through its entire length like mid-ocean swells. 
 Another pier is called the stargazing pier, with soft lighting and, screened from the shore lights, reclined seating -- ''stargazer chaises.'' The park goes down to the shoreline, and it is possible to pick your way through the wild grasses and washed-up timbers to poke a toe in the water -- a possibility unthinkable half a century ago.
 The two float bridges at Gantry have been painted and spruced up, with big red letters spelling ''Long Island'' legible from across the water. Neither bridge has its original decks with rails, but on one the great, bolted steel hangers extend all the way down to a new wooden deck -- but from the side it is obvious that the hangers do not support it but are just tacked on.
 Over on the Hudson, the Balsley firm's design for Riverside Park South is gradually being carried out, although parts have been in place for several years. In the afternoon sunlight, the bright cottony tops of swaths of wild grasses look like a snowfield, and the shore-side walking paths sinuously weave south along the river. 
 The park's modern pier projects far out into the river -- about two dozen New Yorkers went to its farthest end on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, where they saw the fall of the north tower of the World Trade Center and the smoke and devastation that followed the terrorist attack. As the tower's red and white television tower wobbled, a ring of flame blazed out from 10 floors down, but no one could hear the sound of the collapse -- the air was thick with groans, shrieks and prayers. 
 The pier and its furnishings are more modest than at Gantry, and thus the Hudson River pier seems to focus on the 69th Street transfer bridge -- which looks as derelict as a Rust Belt steel plant decades after the final closing whistle. Just to the bridge's south are two older transfer bridges, both pitching down into the water. One, of half-burned timbers, looks like a 19th-century shipwreck; the other, of deeply rusted plate steel, could be a landing craft abandoned on Iwo Jima.
 Mr. Flagg, who knows the site well, says that the 1911 bridge is much more intact than those at Long Island City -- it still has the actual bridge decks -- and that if someone would free up the gearing and restore the electrical system, it could operate again.
 The city is beginning to develop designs for renovating the West 69th Street float bridge -- and the different structures in the two parks show the importance of context in judging what might otherwise be considered an independent work of architecture.
 At Gantry Plaza State Park, the spiffed up ironwork and fresh paint seem in accord with the spacious, open-sky site, partly raw industrial landscape and partly the two handsome neo-1940's apartment houses put up in recent years at the adjacent Queens West development. 
 But the raw decay of the float bridge on the Hudson River is set against the backdrop just to the east of the growing cliff of the Trump Place apartment towers on Riverside Boulevard, which will someday stretch from 72nd Street down to 59th. Although those buildings are all nominally different from one another, their hard-brick finishes, blank windows and solid street wall form a rather plain vanilla backdrop that contrasts dramatically with the memento mori of this rusty monument.


GRAPHIC: Photos: INDUSTRIAL ARCHAEOLOGY -- Float bridges at West 69th Street in Riverside Park South in Manhattan, left, and at Gantry Plaza State Park in Hunters Point, Queens, bottom
the bridge at 69th Street in 1911, below. The bridges once transferred freight cars to and from barges. (Photographs by Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)
 (Photo by Office for Metropolitan History)Graphs: ''Mortgage Rates'' shows mortgage rates for the New York region since 2001.(Sources by HSH Associates)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ARCHAEOLOGY (90%); STATE PARKS (90%); TRAINS (90%); RAILROAD ROLLING STOCK (90%); VANDALISM (89%); RAIL FREIGHT (89%); RAIL TRANSPORTATION (89%); ANTHROPOLOGY & ARCHAEOLOGY (89%); MARINE VESSELS (78%); LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE SERVICES (78%); GRAFFITI (71%); BRIDGES & TUNNELS (64%); URBAN RAIL SYSTEMS (64%); PARKS & PLAYGROUNDS (58%) Parks and Other Recreation Areas; Bridges and Tunnels

PERSON: Christopher Gray

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (94%) NEW YORK, USA (94%); NEW JERSEY, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (94%) New York City; Gantry Plaza State Park (NYC); Riverside Park South (NYC)

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 8; Column 2; Sports Desk; BACKTALK: KEEPING SCORE; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 956 words

HEADLINE: Game Theory Posits Measure of Baseball Players' Value

BYLINE: By ALAN SCHWARZ. 
E-mail: keepingscore@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Thresherman's Bakehouse, a coffee shop in Melbourne, Australia, would seem an odd spot for a baseball epiphany. Yet it was over down-under joe that Brian Lonergan, a young economist from Yale, and Ben Polak, his former dissertation adviser, took a bite out of the eternal apple of baseball statistics: determining a season's most valuable player.
 Traditional categories like home runs and on-base percentage are nice, but they represent mere guesses as to how a player's long balls, walks and what-not help his team win. The two game theorists decided several years ago that what the game needed was a system that acknowledged each player's fundamental charge: to do something, large or small and dependent on the situation, to increase his team's probability of winning. 
 So they built it, and now own the most sophisticated method around to measure, among other things, the rightful winners of the 2004 postseason awards, which will be announced starting this week. 
 Were Manny Ramirez's 43 homers and 130 runs batted in truly more valuable to his Red Sox than Gary Sheffield's 36 and 121 were to the Yankees? Did Barry Bonds's whopping 232 walks make him more or less of an M.V.P. than the Dodgers free-swinger Adrian Beltre? And who should take home the American League Cy Young award, the Twins' Johan Santana (20-6, 2.61 earned run average) or the Red Sox' Curt Schilling (21-6, 3.26)?
 The method's logic is actually very simple: every confrontation between pitcher and batter affects, however marginally, each team's chances of winning. With various numbers of outs and men on base, a double or a strikeout or even a runner-advancing grounder either adds or subtracts a specific amount from the inning's run-scoring potential. Depending on the game's inning and score, each of those amounts takes on varying significance to the final outcome.
 ''It's just our way of looking at the world from studying game theory,'' Lonergan said. ''Each team starts the game with even probability, and ends at either 0 or 1. In between, you're looking at what the players are doing for their team.''
 An example: when Beltre stepped to the plate on Aug. 23 with the Dodgers down, 7-4, in the top of the seventh in Montreal, Los Angeles had a 12.17 percent chance of coming back to win. (This percentage, derived from extensive data from the entire season, would have been 1.29 percent if there were two out in the ninth.) Beltre delivered an R.B.I. single, making the score 7-5 and the Dodgers' chances of winning 19.11 percent.
 So Beltre was awarded with the difference in percentages, or 0.0694, of what Lonergan and Polak call Wins Relative to Average Player (WRAP); and on the other side of baseball's double-entry bookkeeping, the pitcher who surrendered the hit, Luis Ayala, was credited with a minus 0.0694.
 Applied to each of the roughly 186,000 major league plate appearances this season -- from every first-inning sacrifice fly to every game-ending home run -- the resulting aggregate WRAP number tells almost exactly how many pieces of victories a player accounted for.
 ''It has to add up,'' said Polak, a British expatriate whose accent makes the analysis of baseball statistics seem almost urbane. ''It has to add up to a team's number of wins above .500. It's quite beautiful.''
 And a great way to assess the award races. WRAP's verdicts follow.
 A.L. M.V.P. Sheffield, with a 5.60 WRAP, edges out the Angels slugger Vladimir Guerrero (4.45). Ramirez ranks sixth because more of his hits came in game situations that did not have a big effect on the outcome of Boston games.
 N.L. M.V.P. Bonds (12.16) tramples the runner-up, Albert Pujols of the Cardinals (6.85), demonstrating that Bonds's walks did indeed help the Giants by setting the table for subsequent, however disappointing, hitters.
 A.L. CY YOUNG Despite having a higher E.R.A., Schilling tops Santana, 5.15 to 5.01, because he often performed in hitter-friendly Fenway Park (yes, WRAP accounts for this) and because he thrived in particularly tight situations. But the two were bested by Twins closer Joe Nathan (5.47), whose 1.62 E.R.A. and 44 saves do not truly quantify how many games his late pitching helped decide. (WRAP leans toward relievers because, although they influence fewer at-bats, the at-bats are inherently more crucial.)
 N.L. CY YOUNG Once again, closers dominate, with the Dodgers' Eric Gagne (5.69) beating the Astros' Brad Lidge (5.55). San Francisco's Jason Schmidt (5.39) wins among starters, well ahead of the more popular candidates for postseason awards, Randy Johnson of Arizona and Roger Clemens of Houston.
 This probability-based approach isn't necessarily new. In 1969, two brothers involved in military computing, Harlan and Eldon Mills, took a similar tack and published a small book, ''Player Win Averages,'' evangelizing their method. 
 ''It didn't catch on,'' said Eldon Mills, now 83 and living in a Florida retirement community. ''I still can't figure out why.'' 
 Other amateur baseball scientists working in anonymity have traveled related roads.
 Lonergan and Polak still have refinements to make. The damage done by fielding errors must be assessed to the culprit. And while WRAP does a great job in determining value in a finished season, its reliance on clutch performance -- which has been proved to be quite ephemeral -- saps some of its predictive possibilities.
 But the method, with its linchpin in logic, will almost certainly find acceptance in baseball's new statistical age. Told of the approach, a high-ranking team executive declined to comment. He simply asked for Lonergan's and Polak's phone numbers so he could be first in line for licensing. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: BASEBALL (94%); SPORTS AWARDS (90%); ATHLETES (78%) Baseball; Awards, Decorations and Honors

ORGANIZATION: BOSTON RED SOX (82%); NEW YORK YANKEES (55%); MINNESOTA TWINS (54%)

PERSON: Alan Schwarz

GEOGRAPHIC: MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA (73%); LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (54%) VICTORIA, AUSTRALIA (73%); CALIFORNIA, USA (54%) AUSTRALIA (73%); UNITED STATES (54%)

LOAD-DATE: November 7, 2004



152 of 658 DOCUMENTS


Copyright 2004 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 7, 2004
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 31

LENGTH: 4047 words

HEADLINE: The Confessions of John Patrick Shanley

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel. 
Alex Witchel is a staff writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
How can you pass up a chance to attend a family reunion with an Oscar winner who got up and thanked ''everybody who ever punched or kissed me in my life and everybody who I ever punched or kissed?'' Think of the drama, the intrigue, the ice packs. But in a park in Rockland County, N.Y., on a September Saturday, there was nary an Irish temper in sight. The men in John Patrick Shanley's family toted bags of charcoal, raw meat and tongs. The women, like the Italian characters in Shanley's original screenplay for ''Moonstruck,'' unwrapped enormous bowls of pasta salad and oversize platters of deli sandwiches, more than enough for 40. Everyone shared, hugged, talked, showed pictures and yelled at their kids to stay out of the brook. 
 Shanley, the youngest of five, father of two, drove up from Manhattan with his sons. He traveled light, taking only a badminton set, two sandwiches from Gourmet Garage and a reporter for The New York Times. Within minutes, the rest of the family had swarmed to the far side of the table, a spontaneous quarantine. 
 They knew that come November, Shanley, 54, would have three plays opening in New York. They also knew that the curse of having a writer in the family is that everything -- sooner or later -- becomes material. Witness the new lineup: ''Doubt,'' inspired by a relative's experience with a priest who was convicted of child molestation, opens Nov. 22 at Manhattan Theater Club. ''Sailor's Song,'' a lyrical meditation on choosing to love in the face of death, written after Shanley's mother, father and eldest sister all died within an 18-month period, opens Sunday in a LAByrinth Theater Company production at the Public Theater. And a revival of ''Danny and the Deep Blue Sea,'' Shanley's 1984 two-character play about desperate loners afraid of love (think the very dark side of Nicolas Cage and Cher in ''Moonstruck''), opens on Wednesday at Second Stage Theater.
 They also knew that it was Shanley's tormented relationship with his mother that became the template for many of his physically and emotionally damaged or maimed male characters (remember Cage's wooden hand?) who must face down a profusion of often indifferent, always ambivalent females. No, certainly no need to go there during a family reunion. Though of their mother, Shanley's older brother, Tom, said gallantly: ''Up to and including me, my mom's batting arm was still good. By the time John came along she was worn out. But I always, always felt loved. She probably didn't hit me enough.''
 Shanley only smiled. Those requiring further instruction can refer to ''Where's My Money?'' (2001), his scathing play about divorce, in which a male lawyer says, ''Women consume, and they must be directed what to consume, or they may identify you as lunch.'' From the same play comes one of Shanley's most quoted lines: ''Monogamy is like a 40-watt bulb. It works, but it's not enough.''
 Although it was the angst of finding love in and beyond the kind of volatile Irish-American family Eugene O'Neill would recognize that dominated Shanley's earlier plays, it was his biting humor that aligned his work with the surreal domestic comedies of John Guare and Christopher Durang. Shanley has since found increasingly larger canvases for his rage: in last year's political allegory, ''Dirty Story,'' he portrayed the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as a sadomasochistic relationship between a man and a woman. In The New York Times, Ben Brantley called it ''appallingly entertaining,'' going on to say that Shanley's ''broadening of perspective has led him to create one of the liveliest, boldest and -- against the odds -- funniest studies ever of a subject that even hard-core satirists tend to approach on tiptoe.''
 It surprises no one that Shanley's triple crown -- two new plays and a revival -- skirts Broadway, a bottom-line marketplace where ''tiptoe'' rules, and where his plays have never been produced. As Robyn Goodman, a producer of ''Avenue Q,'' last season's Tony Award winner for Best Musical, said: ''When John wants to make a lot of money, he writes 'Moonstruck.' When he writes from his heart as an artist, he's not thinking of mass appeal.''
 For Shanley, writing was how he learned to make sense of a childhood in which he was always an outsider. Growing up as a son of an immigrant meat packer in the east Bronx in the 50's and 60's put him in ''a very violent neighborhood,'' he said. ''It was extremely anti-intellectual and extremely racist and none of this fit me. I was in constant fistfights from the time I was 6. I did not particularly want to be. People would look at me and become enraged at the sight of me. I believe that the reason was they could see that I saw them. And they didn't like that.''
 His hyperdeveloped skills of observation have afforded him a lifetime of highs and lows. The hard-knocks childhood gave way to a stateside stint in the Marines during Vietnam; a meteoric rise in Hollywood with the success of ''Moonstruck'' led to a meteoric crash after writing and directing the catastrophe that was ''Joe Versus the Volcano.'' An impassioned rededication to the theater followed. Shanley's 23 plays, many of which he has also directed, have been translated into 15 languages, performed in 17 countries and receive about 80 productions a year in the United States and Canada. Both his marriages failed, replaced by, as one theater producer put it, ''a different blonde on his arm every night,'' Kim Cattrall among them. Recently, in a cruel twist, he weathered a siege of glaucoma that has cost him 50 percent of his sight yet, incredibly, has slowed his work pace not at all. 
 With a history this tumultuous, perhaps it is best to trace its particulars away from the convivial crowd by the brook. Though the quarantine held, Shanley's Aunt Peggy, his mother's only surviving sister, did make room on a picnic bench to offer her own assessment of her nephew's work. ''It's all in his head,'' she confided. ''I think every kid thinks he had a hard time.''
 She went on to recall that Shanley's father, who came here at 24 from County Westmeath, used to admonish his youngest son to ''get a real job.'' And he did. Before he won his Oscar, Shanley worked as an elevator operator, a house painter, furniture mover, locksmith, bartender and sandwich maker. But looking and listening and telling a story was the only job that stuck. 
Shanley lives on a sunny block in Brooklyn Heights, in a modest apartment building without a doorman. There is color everywhere; bright blue walls in the living room, bright green in the kitchen. There are two small bedrooms, one for Nick and Frank, Shanley's sons (named for his parents, Nicholas and Frances), who come on the weekends. In the otherwise meticulously clean bathroom, a white strand of dental floss lay on the white tiled floor. Like the white birdie at the reunion that flew at him across the badminton net against the white light of the sky, Shanley could not see it.
 He sat at a large dining-room table across from his desk, which was jammed with scripts. Above his computer, a framed handmade sign read ''Make Me.'' A multicolored glass chandelier from Provence hung in the center of the room; another was in the entrance hall.
 ''That was what they called me in the Bronx,'' he said. ''They said: Your name's Shanley? We'll call you Chandelier. Then it became just 'Lier.' '' He pronounced it ''Leah.'' Along with his huge, bursting laugh, the Bronx comes and goes when Shanley speaks, though it doesn't stray far. The kid from the hot-lunch program who never saw a play until he worked on a high-school production of ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' broke through barriers of class and education to become one of the theater's most successful playwrights. He wears that victory lightly, although the courtly, cagey manners of an outsider -- always gauging a response, planning a parry -- tend to peek through. He rarely disagrees; he simply restates someone else's opinion until it resembles his own. He seems open and often is, displaying the flamboyance, warmth and humor that have shaped many of his characters. Just as frequently, he will catch himself and draw back. His lips purse, a heady, distancing speech begins and he is gone.
 These days, Shanley is dancer thin, and against his graying hair, his blue eyes are vivid. But after five operations they tend to flash unexpectedly, disconcertingly, revealing what look like shards of mirror, a writer's fun-house distortion that seems to dare the person before him: Do you see what I see? 
 From the beginning, Shanley went to Catholic schools. The Sisters of Charity, who ran St. Anthony's Grammar School, which he attended in the Bronx and has written about in ''Doubt,'' were the sympathetic antithesis to the Irish Christian Brothers who ran Cardinal Spellman High School. ''They beat children with their fists,'' Shanley said. ''I saw a 220-pound brother put a boy, a little gangly boy, against a wall and hit him in the stomach as hard as he could.'' 
 Shanley's response to that environment was to become a professional problem child. In religion class, he insisted he did not believe in God. In the cafeteria, he flung mashed potatoes over his shoulder often enough to get banned from the hot-lunch program. He read science fiction books during all his classes and spent five days a week, every week for most of the two years he was there in detention before the brothers finally kicked him out.
 He went instead to the Thomas Moore Preparatory School, a private school with a Catholic orientation, in Harrisville, N.H., which afforded him a few humane teachers. It was their kindness, actually, that was among the reasons he wrote ''Doubt,'' in which a nun suspects a priest of being a bit too interested in a young boy. The strength of the play is how skillfully Shanley exposes the two sides to every suspicion.
 ''It was homosexual teachers for the most part who saved me,'' Shanley said. ''The head of discipline at Thomas Moore was gay, and he was my friend and protector. Did he have his reasons for being interested in me? Everybody has their reasons. Passion fuels many things, and it's used in many ways. Many of these people never cross the line.''
 Shanley's relative, unfortunately, was not as lucky. ''A child in my family was molested by a priest,'' he said. ''The parents went first to the local level, then up the chain of command to a highly placed church official, who took them by the hands and said: 'I'm so sorry this happened to you. I will take care of it.' And then he promoted him. They were so shocked that they left the church for 10 years. But they missed it, so they returned to a parish where the monsignor gave a sermon saying that with these church scandals it was the parents, not the clergy, who were responsible. They had to leave the church again.
 ''And still another reason I wrote this play is that I'm very aware that debate has become the form of communication, like on 'Crossfire.' There is no room or value placed on doubt, which is one of the hallmarks of the wise man. It's getting harder and harder in this society to find a place for spacious, true intellectual exchange. It's all becoming about who won the argument, which is just moronic.'' 
 ''Sailor's Song'' -- an emotionally raw piece about a man whose wife is dying, the nephew who keeps him company during her coma and the two women he meets in a bar, one of whom channels the dead -- mines his grief over his parents' and sister's deaths. When he began to speak about his father, Nicholas, his ''good parent,'' who died in 2001 at 95, he turned away and wept.
 ''He was this guy from the land with the ability to forcefully say the thing that needed to be said or to make the observation that cut away everything and revealed the essence of the situation,'' Shanley said. ''He was very affectionate, but from about 20 feet away. He would scream as if there was a chasm, 'I love you, boy!' He was not violent to me, but my oldest brother, Jim, said a curse word when he was, I think, 5 years old, and my father punched him with a closed fist. By the time I showed up he had deeply mellowed out. He slapped me once at my mother's repeated exhortation -- 'Hit him, Nick! Hit him' -- and I could see it broke his heart to do it. He didn't have it in him anymore.'' 
 Shanley's mother died in 2002. So what was the problem, exactly?
 ''She was a pill,'' he said. ''It took me many years of thinking, reading psychological tomes of various kinds, talking endlessly, writing plays, to finally say: 'You know, she was a pill. That was the problem.' And in my climactic interchange with my mother, she called me up and said: 'What was it? What was so terrible?' And I said very easily, very kindly really, 'Well, you just weren't very affectionate.' And she said, 'No, that's not how I am.' And that was the conversation. To get to that was a byzantine, tortuous road. But that was the crux of it. These things always end up being pretty simple.''
 Not really. In Shanley's ''Beggars in the House of Plenty'' (1991), Pop, a butcher, terrorizes his eldest son with a cleaver and says: ''You'll look for love to stop the starving thing in you that I put there, but nothing will stop the starving thing. I'll never approve of you.'' In the same play, Ma bemoans her recurrent headaches.
 ''My mother wasn't comfortable with me no matter what I did,'' Shanley said. ''When I was a kid, she had these terrible headaches, and was always screaming, 'Jesus, Mary and Joseph, I've got a splitting headache!' And many years later I said, 'Do you still get headaches?' And she said: 'What are you talking about? I don't get headaches.' I said, 'Wait a minute, when I was growing up you had headaches all the time.' And she thought about it and went: 'Oh, yeah. That's true.' I said, 'When did they stop?' She said, 'When you left.'''
 He went on: ''I remember I'd asked if she had seen 'Five Corners,' my first movie. And she said: 'No, I haven't. I understand the mother is thrown out the window in that movie.' And I said, 'Yeah.' That was the end of that subject.'' 
 Not that his father was terribly different. After Shanley's freshman year at New York University, he was placed on academic probation and dropped out to enlist. He returned to school two years later, putting himself through on a combination of the G.I. Bill, loans and odd jobs. In 1977 he graduated as valedictorian. 
 ''My father said, 'It's not too late to join the Sanitation Department,' '' Shanley recalled. ''But he was kind of joking. I would say that my parents were intermittently proud of me. They couldn't hang onto it, you know? It would come and go, like the flu.''
 Well, beside his ex-wives, there must be a long line of women who would have loved to get their hands around his mother's neck. He laughed. ''Absolutely,'' he said, adding dryly, ''although you do tend to wrestle with the same problem, so you often choose somebody who is going to give you something to work with.''
 It was his second wife, the actress Jayne Haynes, with whom he adopted his sons, who are now 12, in 1992. Through open adoption, he agreed to pay the room and board of two pregnant women, assuming one might change her mind. Neither did. 
 ''We got two children, four and a half months apart,'' Shanley said. ''It was very intense and very hard but ultimately great. Nicky is Mexican-American, from just this side of the Rio Grande. Frankie is a blond, blue-eyed Celt from Texarkana. They're joined at the hip.'' 
 After Shanley's glaucoma was diagnosed, however, it wasn't easy to stop two roughhousing boys from climbing all over Dad. ''The really bad three-year period ended about three years ago,'' he said. When medication failed, surgery became necessary. ''They basically had to puncture the eyes to lower the pressure,'' he continued. ''My eyes deflated, and I went blind in one eye, then in the other, fortunately never at the same time. When you have eye surgery, you have to be awake. They use a topical anesthetic, and by the last surgery I'd become immune to it. I was just in agony. But for some reason it always would time out around productions so that I would go blind and then they would be able to bring back the vision just in time for me to go to work. And then I would be blind in the other eye after I finished that job, and then they'd fix that. 
 ''After the last surgery, the surgeon said, 'You'll take these drops, and if the pressure remains constant, then you're out of the woods.' And he thought for a minute and said, 'Actually, you're never going to be out of the woods.' And I said, 'So I live in the woods now.''' He sighed. ''Look, I can read, I can drive, I can direct plays. But I just, you know, live in a delicate eyeball world.''
 And there's no family history of this? He shook his head. ''None,'' he said. ''Except my mother. Late in life.''
On a rainy morning, Shanley went to the Public Theater to hear the first read-through of ''Sailor's Song.'' With three plays opening almost at once, he made the judicious decision to direct none of them.
 Sitting at a large table, two actresses threw some moony looks Shanley's way; hope springs eternal on the first day of rehearsal. The playwright responded not at all, until the reading began and one of those actresses spoke some lines. ''Phony Baloney,'' he wrote in the margin of his script. An actor stumbled on a speech and, like everyone else who made a mistake, looked guiltily at Shanley, whose benign expression never changed. Though at a certain point, when one character said, ''It can be a curse to love,'' it became clear that the soft panting noise in the room was Shanley, bent in his chair, crying.
 When the reading ended, he went into the lobby of the Public and sat at a cafe table. Even within the theater, Shanley is considered something of an outsider, a tough guy; some of its gay denizens refer to him as Manly John Shanley. But while everyone bows to his talent -- and covets his Oscar -- most people don't know him well. Because he has so often insisted on directing his own work (which has earned him some critical slaps for self-indulgence, when the text might have benefited from an outside eye), some charge that he is, at heart, an arrogant control freak.
 ''I find that people who say I'm a control freak are control freaks themselves,'' Shanley said calmly. ''For them it's about power; for me, it's about ideas. Nothing would be better than to learn in wiser hands than mine. In the past I have tried that and found that the news was not good. I waited to see my work expanded, and instead, I saw it become less than.
 ''I have to fight for what I believe. I came from a background that I wasn't going to be able to capitalize on. If I had, somebody could have gotten me into the telephone company or maybe the Fire Department. I was going to be a writer, and I had never met a writer, and I had never gone to the theater. I was completely having to invent this from scratch. It was going to have to be about my craft and my desire to be heard, and you push your way to the front and say, 'Damn it, you're going to do my play.' That kind of braggadocio and aggressiveness, which was in my case based on real conviction -- was very important.''
 Because ''Moonstruck,'' which grossed about $80 million and won three Oscars, was only his second movie, he didn't have to fight as long or as hard in Hollywood. The time for that would have been in 1990, after ''Joe Versus the Volcano'' bombed. But he chose not to.
 ''When I was in Los Angeles, I was in the above-the-line community pretty much all the time,'' he said. ''And it's a very small group of people who basically reassure each other that they must be doing O.K. because they're in the room with these other people. I found it, after a while, just antithetical to my nature. I like to make a good living, but there are limits to how much cash is good for a person to have coming over the transom every day. It's also addictive. Money is like heroin, and I grew up in a neighborhood that was destroyed by heroin. I've watched addiction all my life. Celebrity is like heroin. And constant praise is like heroin. And, you know, no one can resist constant praise. I had to get out.''
 Shanley has written numerous screenplays since then; four have been produced, including ''Alive'' and ''Congo.'' A script he co-wrote for HBO, ''Live From Baghdad,'' about journalists who covered the 1991 Persian Gulf war, was nominated for an Emmy Award. ''I still make an awful lot of money out of Hollywood,'' he said. ''And once in a while they make something I write. But that's not my raison d'etre.''
 That would be the theater. Tony Kushner, who had a big-time show-biz success of his own with HBO's adaptation of ''Angels in America,'' said of Shanley: ''What I admire most are that his plays are beautifully well made, economical, sharp and coherent. I like the toughness of his writing a lot. He's not a misanthrope, but he's in pursuit of why people behave as badly as they do along with having a great compassion for them. That's an unusual and interesting combination.''
 For Shanley, there is no calling greater: ''Playwriting is the last great bastion of the individual writer. It's exciting precisely because it's where the money isn't. Money goes to safety, to consensus. It's not individualism. That's why sometimes I get very frustrated watching plays. I'm like: 'Man, you have the shot here to say anything and this is what you're saying? This boring retread of a play I've seen 500 times, this denatured Arthur Miller? I mean you could do or say anything that's within the bounds of the law if you don't harm anybody physically, and this is what you're doing?'' He shook his head. ''Theater is just too exciting a prospect to be left to dullards.''
 That less-than-collegial attitude may account for the fact that in the 25 years Shanley has been writing and directing in New York, he has never won an award for either. ''Maybe they think I have enough,'' he said easily, getting up to return to rehearsal. ''And if that's it, that's O.K.'' 
As it is, that Oscar of his is still causing problems.
 While even more family arrived at the reunion, Aunt Peggy was recalling that she and her sister Bessie had gone to see each of Shanley's plays, from the very beginning. ''When he won, we were so disappointed,'' she said. ''He never mentioned our names.''
 But her granddaughter, Mary Murphy, chimed in, ''It's very cool, having a star in the family.''
 The star sat alone, watching Nick and Frank play badminton with cousins, uncles and aunts. When they took a break, conversation centered on starting the sixth grade. At Frank's school, students call teachers by their first names. ''We could have done that, too,'' Shanley said amiably, ''but then we'd be put to death.'' 
 Both boys are protective of Shanley, almost tender in their vigilance of him. They continually surround him, seeming to stand sentry. Maybe it's the glaucoma. Maybe it's because he's just not like other dads. When Frank came off the makeshift court -- a patch of grass dotted with rocks -- and Shanley saw his skinned knee, he said, ''You know, in Ireland, kings were kings until they had a physical imperfection, and then they were put to death.''
 His brother Tom quickly interjected, ''Well, Frank, it's a good thing you're not a king.'' But Frank didn't need reassurance. He seems to hear stuff like that all the time. He sat near his father a while longer, then returned to the game.
 Shanley watched his sons. ''They're going to fall in love and have their hearts broken,'' he said quietly. ''I don't think I can take it.''
 The next time it was Nick who left the court. He wore a silver medallion around his neck, a leadership medal he won at camp. As the apparent conscience of the group, he had determined that there were too many questionable calls on whether the birdie was in or out.
 ''Dad, we need more string,'' he said.
 Shanley seemed puzzled and looked toward the net. ''Why? Is it falling down?''
 Nick shook his head. ''No, no, I want outlines,'' he said, gesturing to the court.
 ''Oh, you want boundaries,'' Shanley said and burst out laughing. ''No, I don't have any of those.''
 Nick smiled before turning to go. Actually, he knew that. 


GRAPHIC: Photos: (Photograph by Gareth McConnell
 'Moon' Glow: Shanley (top) directing Jayne Haynes and John Turturro in his play ''Italian American Reconciliation'' in 1988, the year he won his Oscar for ''Moonstruck.'' After the eclipse of ''Joe Versus the Volcano'' (bottom, 1990), he renewed his commitment to the theater. (Photograph: top: Gerry Goodstein)

LENGTH: 915 words

HEADLINE: After Mixed Results, Suozzi Presses On to Fix Albany

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 5 

 BODY:
For months, Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, has argued that the state is dysfunctional, and he has called for ousting certain incumbents. He formed the Fix Albany political action committee to support challengers, won backing from former New York City Mayor Edward I. Koch and raised $150,000 for the campaign.
 But candidates favored by Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat, failed to defeat two Republican senators whom he had picked out as targets in his own county, Carl L. Marcellino and Dean G. Skelos, the Senate's deputy majority leader. They won re-election by wide margins. In two other races, candidates he supported claimed victories, though the final results are still not in on one and critics belittle Mr. Suozzi's impact on the other. 
 In the end, though, Mr. Suozzi's campaign to fix Albany might turn out to be not only about changing the dynamics in a capital known for its stagnancy and lack of accountability, but also about catapulting Mr. Suozzi to a position where he can be the fixer-in-chief.
 It is a strategy that has worked for him before. He began as mayor of the city of Glen Cove, inheriting the prior Republican regime's deficit and bad credit rating. He imposed a one-time tax increase, cut the staff, improved services, produced surpluses and revitalized the city.
 Next he turned his skills as a municipal Mr. Fix-It to the huge suburban county of Nassau, where Republicans again had run up a big deficit and damaged the credit rating. His campaign slogan was, ''I can do it because I've done it.'' Elected as the first Democratic executive here in three decades, he repeated his Glen Cove script by imposing a one-time tax increase, cutting the staff, improving services, producing surpluses and working on revitalization. 
 Fixing Albany seems like a natural career progression, but political analysts dispute just how well Mr. Suozzi is doing and the latest election's impact. 
 ''He didn't do much fixing'' in this election, said Dr. Stanley B. Klein, a political science professor at C.W. Post College and a Republican. ''As far as impact, he's a thud.''
 Arthur Kremer, a Democrat and former chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, says, however, that ''Tom Suozzi is on to something.''
 ''There's a lot of talk now about reform,'' Mr. Kremer said. ''He was one of the earliest and gets part of the credit that it's on the front burner.'' For his part, Mr. Suozzi says: ''Albany is still broken, but now everybody is using the phrase 'fix Albany.' Everybody is at least talking about reform.''
 In the process, he has raised his profile tremendously around the state by making speeches to various groups in upstate cities and appearing on television across the state.
 ''He certainly won the editorial boards,'' Mr. Kremer said of the numerous newspaper editorials that praised Mr. Suozzi.
 A campaign consultant who works mostly for Republicans, Michael Dawidziak, said: ''For a local elected official, he's doing tremendously well. If he continues to ride this issue, in two years we'll see if it has legs. I think it does, frankly.'' 
 That two-year mark is crucial. The next election of legislators is in 2006, as well as the election for governor, an office that Suozzi supporters say he covets. 
 But while he gained visibility and some support in his campaign, he also made enemies by recruiting Charles D. Lavine to mount a successful primary challenge to Assemblyman David S. Sidikman for the party's nomination in the 13th District on Nassau's North Shore. 
 Party officials called Mr. Suozzi disloyal and even barred him from a delegate's seat at the Democratic National Convention. The Nassau County Legislature's presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, became Mr. Sidikman's campaign manager.
 Political consultants say that the Sidikman upset was a fluke that Mr. Suozzi pulled off only because the district includes Glen Cove, where he dominates the party organization. A big turnout there propelled Mr. Lavine to a narrow victory for the nomination. He won Tuesday's general election, which was expected, given the district's big Democratic base.
 ''It isn't a big deal,'' Dr. Klein said. He added that Mr. Suozzi was unlikely to repeat that success elsewhere because of the special circumstances of the race.
 Mr. Suozzi also claims partial credit for the strong showing upstate by David J. Valesky, the Democrat who challenged a Republican State senator, Nancy Larraine Hoffmann, in the Syracuse area.
 Mr. Suozzi donated money and made appearances for Mr. Valesky, who led in close voting, with thousands of paper ballots still being counted. Echoing Mr. Suozzi's refrain, he said, ''This was the first important step towards fixing the broken State Legislature in Albany.''
 Whatever the significance of the results of Tuesday's election, Mr. Suozzi clearly has not abandoned his campaign. On Thursday, two days after the election, he was again attacking Albany and its system of financing Medicaid -- the heart of his fix-Albany argument. With Westchester's county executive, Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat, by his side, he called on the newly elected legislators to cap the local cost of Medicaid. He was immediately attacked by Senator Skelos's spokesman, Thomas K. Dunham, who labeled their proposal ''a joke'' that ''doesn't make any sense whatsoever.''
 Mr. Suozzi said the fight continues. He will be saying more about the issue in his new role as president of the New York State County Executives' Association, which starts next month.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas R. Suozzi, left, the Nassau County executive, with Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive, in Mineola, N.Y., last week. (Photo by Kirk Condyles for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News Analysis

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: Bruce Lambert; Thomas R (County Exec) Suozzi

HEADLINE: A Vision for Saving Iraq by Preserving Bits of Babylon

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME. 
E-mail: peappl@nytimes.com

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, N.Y. 

 BODY:
THERE was the Iraq of the presidential campaign, a place, almost an abstraction, that often seemed more about us than about them, where all the casualty figures were American and big ideas of freedom and democracy seldom seemed tied to the agony of a real place with real people.
 And then sitting in a conference room at Stony Brook University, there were Helen Malko, Zaid Ibraheem, Zainab Mohammed and Lina Mahmod, all sharing a goal that seems, at the moment, so distant as to be almost a hallucination. 
 The four are Iraqis studying archaeology under a grant from the United States Agency for International Development, learning modern techniques they can use to train a new generation of archaeologists and museum curators back home. The hope is that one day Iraq's cultural treasures dating back 4,000 years will become tourist attractions similar to the pyramids of Egypt. 
 The war zone that is Iraq is, after all, where civilization began. Elizabeth Stone, the Iraqis' teacher, reminds us that it was home to the first cities, the first people who worked full time making pottery and sculpture, where writing first captured the details and accounts of everyday life, the first place to brew beer.
 So there's something at once utterly rational and achingly quixotic in the program here, whose roots, the students said, began with their own experiences, their own awe, at the thousands of historic sites in Iraq, from Babylon and Kish to Ur and Uruk, from Nippur to Zabalam, many of them now being looted and despoiled.
 They know that Iraq's sharing its history with the world is something far in the future. But they don't think it's an empty dream. 
 ''Maybe one day, but not soon, not soon,'' said Ms. Mahmod, whose words tumble out of her mouth in a rush, like birds escaping from a cage.
 In the meantime, the four, ranging in age from 24 to 31, roam the sprawling state university campus here, Ms. Mahmod and Ms. Mohammed, scrupulously covered, Mr. Ibraheem and Ms. Malko blending in with the other students, all of them studying archaeology, studying us and studying us studying them.
 Since the first gulf war, of course, almost no Iraqis have been able to study in the United States. The four students at Stony Brook are among the first Iraqis to study in the United States since the current war began, part of a program offering grants to five universities.
 Much of their education has to do with the puzzle that is the culture of America, a place they see as different, not better, than their home. 
 Asked what seemed most strange, Ms. Mohammed, said: ''the machines'' -- meaning cash machines and ticket machines at rail or subway stations, vending machines in campus dorms, even the prevalence of computers. ''We don't have that in my country,'' she said.
 But just as odd, they said, was the relative isolation in which Americans seemed to live, compared with the close, extended families, their members all living near one another, that define their world in Iraq.
 And then there was the presidential race. 
 ''This is the first time I've seen the president of a very great country and another candidate, together, discussing things, being told he was wrong,'' Ms. Malko said. ''In my own country, never. If you looked at Saddam the wrong way you could be killed.''
 The task they will face when they return home is beyond daunting. Many important sites, particularly in southern Iraq, are in territory not controlled by the government, and just trying to visit can mean death. Iraq's national museum, ransacked after the fall of Saddam's reign, is still missing thousands of pieces and trying to recover from the vandalism of equipment, files and records.
 And another hurdle looms. Dr. Stone said she applied for the grant, with the understanding it would be a three-year program, the time needed for a meaningful master's program. But the money beyond the first year still has not been appropriated, and she has been told that because of the disastrous course of the war, education may be an unaffordable luxury and the money might go to security instead. 
 All four have lost friends or relatives since the war began. They accept the likelihood that they could lose more. They think removing Saddam was a good thing, but for now things in their country are worse than when he was there -- no jobs, no security, no peace.
 Like many Americans, it seems, they are surer about their religious faith than the world around them, their response to the chaos at home, part anger, part hope, part acceptance. If this quixotic dream of education, restoration and renewal falls through, one suspects they will accept that, too.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Zainab Mohammed, foreground, and Zaid Ibraheem at Stony Brook University. The archaeology students will share what they have learned when they return to Iraq. (Photo by Kirk Condyles for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ARCHAEOLOGY (92%); ANTHROPOLOGY & ARCHAEOLOGY (91%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (89%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (89%); DESERT STORM (78%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); SCULPTURE (78%); STUDENT HOUSING (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (76%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (75%); WAR & CONFLICT (74%); DESTINATIONS & ATTRACTIONS (74%); GRANTS & GIFTS (70%); RAIL STATIONS & TERMINALS (69%); HISTORIC SITES (69%) Foreign Study, Teaching and Travel; Archaeology and Anthropology; Colleges and Universities

ORGANIZATION: AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (59%); US AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (57%) State University of New York at Stony Brook; Agency for International Development (Aid)
